authors: Brad Wenner, Elizabeth Berryhill, Steve Streisguth, Irving Pham, Matthew Thompson

entries: Physical copies of this zine were sent as an invitation to players of Dungeon Church in 2021. This is the start of our homebrew setting, Pyora.

entries.name: Original Zine
entries: The original, printable form of this zine in PDF format is {@link available here|https://www.dungeon.church/zine-no1}.

entries.name: Current Timelines
entries: Are available in {@link the lore wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/s/zine-1}.

data.name: Pyora
entries: Several centuries after the fall of the {@link Last Dragon Emperor|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/dragon-empire-odzVqtQPbm}, civilization in the lands of Pyora has entered a new period of innovation & transition.

{@race Human (Pyoran)|dungeonchurch|Humans} have labored to carve out pockets of order among the wilderness & ruins of the last age, rebuilding cities, establishing trade routes, and mastering the wild lands into agriculture. In the villages on the edges of humanity's reach, rumors and superstitions percolate about {@race Elfmarked|dungeonchurch} children born with unexplainable talents, echoes of long vanished Elven heroes.

The {@race Dwarf (Durandar)|dungeonchurch|Dwarven} Kingdom has nearly finished the long Great Migration - abandoning their old cities to follow their {@link Prophet-King|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/king-olfgard-wisebeard-S0YDu9xGHy} across the Azure Sea and into the mountains of the west. Their new granite city of {@link Durandar|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/durandar-sWDxZHDVIC} rises as a center of technological innovation, as the dwarves reject magic in favor of molding the mountain's inner fire and rivers into great power.

The {@race Dragonborn (Pyoran)|dungeonchurch|Dragonborn}, once the conscripted foot soldiers of the {@link Empire's|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/dragon-empire-odzVqtQPbm} army, have been instrumental in the reclaiming of the port of {@link New Galmaarden|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/new-galmaarden-03tcpxxc2t} into a {@link democratic city|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/new-galmaarden-civil-society-AjPbwTWHao} with free elections in the east. Others seek out a simpler life among the {@race Tribeborn|dungeonchurch} in the vast wilderness - away from the wars & schemes of humanity.

Between the two new cities lies the older human stronghold, {@link Striborg|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/striborg-mZk9jSyJUV}, at a crucial trade point on the peninsula. With it's well funded naval control of the strait and ambitious aristocratic ruling class, the city's influence extends far beyond it's walls as the hoofsteps of the {@link Iron Riders|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/iron-riders-of-abraxas-P77pTaxjou} echo down the newly safe roads throughout the land.

Beneath this veneer of progress & opportunity, the old threats still lurk, plotting for their moment to reemerge and propel the {@link endless cycle of fate & magic|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/session-01-ouroboros-turns-MlX7v5L4dN} forward again.

data.name: Saltmarsh
entries: Nestled on the eastern coast of the Azure Sea is {@link Saltmarsh|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/saltmarsh-GkGI6ISio5}, a sleepy fishing village thats sits on the precipice of great change.

Smugglers guide their ships to hidden coves, willing to slit the throat of any who cross their path. Soldiers of a faraway power patrol the roads mounted on armored horses. Monsters gather beneath the waves & drowned sailors stir to unnatural life, animated by dark magic. The cult of a dead god silently grows it's reach. The nearby woods house mind-bending horrors. Mercenary groups seek abandoned treasures in the old dwarven mine.
As Saltmarsh sleeps each night, waves gently lapping against the docks, the forces that seek to plunder it grow stronger.

data.name: Players
entries: You have been invited to join our in-person Dungeons & Dragons campaign.
We will play an ongoing, narrative-focused game in a world of our own creation.
The story of that world has already begun to be told, what role will you play?

entries.name: If you're reading this in the present...
entries: ...and you live in the SF Bay area, you can fill out this form to {@link join us|https://www.dungeon.church/join-us}.
Playable character species were limited to these options at the inception of Pyora.

entries.name: {@race Human (Pyoran)|dungeonchurch|Humans}
entries: The most common species by far, humans have built their cities, expanded their roads, and in general sought order in the world.

Human ambition is embodied in the prosperous merchant city of Striborg. Ruled by an aristocratic merchant class, with a rising religious-populous movement in the streets, Striborg has become a place increasingly unwelcome to those not committed to human partisanship in some form.

Most humans do not live in {@link Striborg|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/striborg-mZk9jSyJUV} though, but in simple settlements throughout the continent. These people are driven by more basic motivations: farmers, craftsmen, travelers, scholars, and adventurers.

entries.name: Dwarves ({@race Dwarf (Durandar)|dungeonchurch|Durandar} or {@race Dwarf (Road)|dungeonchurch|Road})
entries: It's taken centuries for {@link King Olfgard Wisebeard|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/king-olfgard-wisebeard-S0YDu9xGHy} to convince the majority of the dwarven tribes to abandon their homes and build the new granite city of {@link Durandar|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/durandar-sWDxZHDVIC} under the mountain. Opposed to the use of magic, the dwarves there dedicate themselves to alchemy & artificing, building great forges, damming the power of the rivers, and preparing for the apocalypse that's been foretold.

But dwarves are stubborn & not everyone has gone along. Some have stayed behind, adapting to the flood of newcomers to the old cities, while others have sought fortune on the continent as independent merchants or hireswords.
It is rumored that the pirates who plague {@link Striborg's merchant ships|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/striborg-navy-ndvIs6jZtX} are dwarves who prefer the open sea.

entries.name: Elves
entries: It is known that elves played a prominent role in fighting the Dragon Empires in the last age, but no one in living memory can remember seeing one in the flesh except for the oldest dwarves.
According to legends and the tall tales of lost hunters, they have built an advanced civilization in the deep forests, but no one has ever pinpointed the exact location of any settlement or ruin.
[Players will not play elves... for now]

entries.name: {@race Elfmarked|dungeonchurch}
entries: According to superstitions common in the villages, children who exhibit certain talents, deformities, or spurious lineage are called 'Children of the Travelers' a.k.a. the elfmarked.

Many stories, or convenient excuses, of individuals being charmed into illicit encounters with elves have been reported over the centuries. Sometimes the rumors claim whole towns were bewitched into bacchanal acts, or driven mad in carnivals beyond comprehension, only to find themselves not only hungover - but bearing a generation of progeny that can only be called special.
More skeptical minds consider these children to have been exposed to magic in the womb, or to be the resurgence of recessive traits from pre-human species lost to the cycle of time.

entries.name: {@race Dragonborn (Pyoran)|dungeonchurch|Dragonborn}
entries: Forged by the {@link First Dragon Emperor|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/dragon-empire-odzVqtQPbm#h-emperors} as an unholy magical corruption of humanity, the slaves that conquered and then built the First Empire.
Finally freed of their wyrm master, the former conscripts have since proven their resilience and independent nature despite lingering doubts about their true allegiances.

Many of the dispossessed dragonborn have been instrumental in reclaiming the abandoned dwarven port of {@link New Galmaarden|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/new-galmaarden-03tcpxxc2t} and building a thriving free city where it is said, 'every man a king.'
Others have sought to create a new history and culture that they were denied, living tribal lives in the wilderness.

entries.name: {@race Gnome (Rock)|dungeonchurch|Gnomes} & {@race Halfling (Pyoran)|dungeonchurch|Halflings}
entries: The diminutive little people, gnomes live below ground and guard their homeland with a jealous secrecy that few have glimpsed.
Their dealings with the civilizations above ground is limited to trade, where they are known for intricate craftsmanship and ingenious devices.
Some gnomes have come to live on the surface and assimilate to human life - known as halflings - as in half-humans.

condition.name: Intoxicated
entries: An intoxicated creature has disadvantage on attack rolls and ability checks. To cast a spell, the creature must first succeed a DC 10 Constitution check. Otherwise, the spellcasting action is wasted, but the spell is not.

language.name: Adalindian Whistling
entries: A secret, whistled language used by the Gnomish resistance movement {@link Hand of Adalind|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/hand-of-adalind-kFepjGY6vb}.

language.name: Tribal
entries: Tribal is a harsh, grating language with hard consonants used mostly by the {@race Tribeborn|dungeonchurch} of the southwest. It has no script of its own but is written in the Dwarvish script.

entries.name: Age
entries: The Elfmarked mature at the same rate humans do and reach adulthood around the age of 20. They live much longer than humans, however, often exceeding 180 years.

entries.name: Size
entries: The Elfmarked are about the same size as humans, ranging from 5 to 6 feet tall. Your size is Medium.

entries.name: Darkvision
entries: Thanks to your elven heritage, you have superior vision in dark and dim conditions. You can see in dim light within 60 feet of you as if it were bright light, and in darkness as if it were dim light. You can't discern color in darkness, only shades of gray.

entries.name: Elven Ancestry
entries: You have advantage on saving throws against being {@condition charmed}, and magic can't put you to sleep.

entries.name: Skill Versatility
entries: You gain proficiency in two skills of your choice.

entries.name: Languages
entries: You can speak, read, and write Common and two extra languages of your choice.
According to superstitions common in the villages, children who exhibit certain talents, deformities, or spurious lineage are called “Children of the Travelers” a.k.a. the elfmarked.

Many stories - or convenient excuses - of individuals being charmed into illicit encounters with elves have been reported over the centuries. Sometimes the rumors claim whole towns were bewitched into bacchanal acts, or driven mad in carnivals beyond comprehension, only to find themselves not only hungover - but bearing a generation of progeny that can only be called special.
More skeptical minds consider these children to have been exposed to magic in the womb, or to be the resurgence of recessive traits from pre-human species lost to the cycle of time.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about the {@link Elfmarked in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/elfmarked-ohkfCOb0aT}.

entries.name: Age
entries: A halfling reaches adulthood at the age of 20 and generally lives into the middle of his or her second century.

entries.name: Size
entries: Halflings average about 3 feet tall and weigh about 40 pounds. Your size is Small.

entries.name: Lucky
entries: When you roll a 1 on an attack roll, ability check, or saving throw, you can reroll the die and must use the new roll.

entries.name: Brave
entries: You have advantage on saving throws against being {@condition frightened}.

entries.name: Halfling Nimbleness
entries: You can move through the space of any creature that is of a size larger than yours.

entries.name: Languages
entries: You can speak, read, and write Common and Gnomish. The Gnomish language isn't secret, but halflings are loath to share it with others. They write very little, so they don't have a rich body of literature. Their oral tradition, however, is very strong. Almost all halflings speak Common to converse with the people in whose lands they dwell or through which they are traveling.

entries.name: Stone Tea
entries: You have proficiency with {@item Gnomish Tea Set|dungeonchurch}. Gnomes and halflings who come from Underdark society know the secret of the Stone Tea brew, and an individual with a week’s preparation time and the proper ingredients can summon enough magic to imbue a single tea ceremony ritual with {@spell Stone Shape}. However, Stone Tea is known to induce erratic behavior individuals who are regularly exposed to sunlight.

The diminutive little people, gnomes live below ground and guard their homeland with a jealous secrecy that few have glimpsed. their dealings with the civilizations above ground is limited to trade, where they are known for intricate craftsmanship and ingenious devices.

Some gnomes have come to live on the surface and assimilate to human life - known as halflings - as in half-humans. These people tend to be nomadic and independent, with an intrinsic wanderlust that led them out of the Underdark and away from their traditional culture and lifestyle underground.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about {@link Halflings in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/halfling-fFZiVbQDbC}.

entries.name: Age
entries: Humans reach adulthood in their late teens and live less than a century.

entries.name: Size
entries: Humans vary widely in height and build, from barely 5 feet to well over 6 feet tall. Regardless of your position in that range, your size is Medium.

entries.name: Skills
entries: You gain proficiency in one skill of your choice.

entries.name: Feat
entries: You gain one feat of your choice.

entries.name: Languages
entries: You can speak, read, and write Common and one extra language of your choice. Humans typically learn the languages of other peoples they deal with, including obscure dialects. They are fond of sprinkling their speech with words borrowed from other tongues: Orc curses, Elvish musical expressions, Dwarvish military phrases, and so on.
The most common species by far, humans have built their cities, expanded their roads, and in general sought order in the world.

Human ambition is embodied in the prosperous merchant city of {@link Striborg|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/striborg-mZk9jSyJUV}. Ruled by an aristocratic merchant class, with a rising religious-populous movement in the streets, Striborg has become a place increasingly unwelcome to those not committed to human partisanship in some form.

Most humans do not live in Striborg though, but in simple settlements throughout the continent. These people are driven by more basic motivations: farmers, craftsmen, travelers, scholars, and adventurers.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about {@link Humans in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/human-pyoran-LMuc7qNrv4}.

entries.name: Age
entries: Ravenfolk reach adulthood at 10 years old, and can live to be 110.

entries.name: Size
entries: Ravenfolk are slighter and shorter than humans. They range from 4 feet to just shy of 6 feet tall. Your size is Small or Medium.

entries.name: Sudden Attack
entries: You have advantage on attack rolls against a surprised creature.

entries.name: Mimicry
entries: Ravenfolk can mimic any sound they've heard. Make a Charisma {@skill Deception} check against the passive {@skill Insight} of any listeners. Success indicates they believe the sound you created was real.

entries.name: Trickster
entries: You have proficiency in the {@skill Deception} and {@skill Stealth} skills.

entries.name: Languages
entries: You can mimic Common perfectly and 3 additional languages poorly.

Few live amid so much rumor, suspicion, and outright falsehood as the ravenfolk. Depending on whom you ask, they might condemn the ravenfolk as nomads bearing misfortune or praise them as messengers from the gods. Ravenfolk are loyal comrades and treacherous thieves, brave warriors and contemptible cowards. They are despised for their strange and secretive nature, and criticized for having no true culture - only mimicry. These contradictions conceal a greater mystery few understand or know.

The Ravenfolk are the ethereal wanderers and messengers of Pyora, born from the celestial drama of deities and their caprices. They emerged from the feathers of {@link Eve|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/eve-QQyGI5YbZc}, the winged consort of the {@deity Raven Queen|pyora|dungeonchurch}, who, in a fit of jealousy clipped Eve's wings to keep her faithful. These feathers, cast into the nether regions of the planes, took on life and consciousness, becoming the {@race Ravenfolk|dungeonchurch}.
Cast out from their home, the Ravenfolk traverse the myriad planes of existence, seeking redemption and a path back to the favor of the Raven Queen.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about the {@link Ravenfolk in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/ravenfolk-2FqUStq1FR}.

entries.name: Age
entries: Tribeborn mature a little faster than humans, reaching adulthood around age 14. They age noticeably faster and rarely live longer than 75 years.

entries.name: Size
entries: Tribeborn are somewhat larger and bulkier than humans, and they range from 5 to well over 6 feet tall. Your size is Medium.

entries.name: Darkvision
entries: Thanks to your tribal upbringing, you have superior vision in dark and dim conditions. You can see in dim light within 60 feet of you as if it were bright light, and in darkness as if it were dim light. You can't discern color in darkness, only shades of gray.

entries.name: Tribal Resilience
entries: You gain proficiency in {@skill Survival}

entries.name: Relentless Endurance
entries: When you are reduced to 0 hit points but not killed outright, you can drop to 1 hit point instead. You can't use this feature again until you finish a long rest.

entries.name: Savage Attacks
entries: When you score a critical hit with a melee weapon attack, you can roll one of the weapon's damage dice one additional time and add it to the extra damage of the critical hit.

entries.name: Languages
entries: You can speak, read, and write Common and Tribal. Tribal is a harsh, grating language with hard consonants. It has no script of its own but is written in the Dwarvish script.

The Tribeborn are a formidable and resilient people, born of the union between orcs and other species. Deeply connected to their tribal settlements in the wilderness of the southwestern jungles, they embody a fusion of the primal strength of their orcish heritage with the varied traits of Pyora's diversity.

Tribeborn often inherit the physical prowess and stature of orcs, characterized by robust builds and distinct features such as prominent jaws and tusk-like teeth. Their skin tones range from deep greens to earthy browns, often marked with tribal tattoos or scars from rites of passage.

Tribeborn are deeply communal, valuing the bonds of their tribe above all. They are raised with a strong sense of loyalty and often act as protectors of their people and the wild lands they call home. Their communities are tight-knit, with traditions and customs passed down through generations.
They are not common in the urban cities of Pyora, preferring to live apart from broader society.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about the {@link Tribeborn in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/tribeborn-KVgPsdxk3f}.

Forged by the {@link First Dragon Emperor|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/dragon-empire-odzVqtQPbm#h-emperors} as an unholy magical corruption of humanity, the slaves that conquered and then built the First Empire.
Finally freed of their wyrm master, the former conscripts have since proven their resilience and independent nature despite lingering doubts about their true allegiances.

Many of the dispossessed dragonborn have been instrumental in reclaiming the abandoned dwarven port of {@link New Galmaarden|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/new-galmaarden-03tcpxxc2t} and building a thriving free city where it is said, 'every man a king.'
Others have sought to create a new history and culture that they were denied, living tribal lives in the wilderness.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about the {@link Dragonborn in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/dragonborn-pyoran-Pd8mdtKo6V}.

entries.name: Artificer's Lore
entries: Whenever you make an Intelligence {@skill History} check related to magic items, alchemical objects, or technological devices, you can add twice your proficiency bonus, instead of any proficiency bonus you normally apply.

entries.name: Stone Tea
entries: You have proficiency with {@item Gnomish Tea Set|dungeonchurch}. Gnomes and halflings who come from Underdark society know the secret of the Stone Tea brew, and an individual with a week’s preparation time and the proper ingredients can summon enough magic to imbue a single tea ceremony ritual with {@spell Stone Shape}. However, Stone Tea is known to induce erratic behavior individuals who are regularly exposed to sunlight.

entries.name: Tinker
entries: You have proficiency with {@item tinker's tools|phb}. Using those tools, you can spend 1 hour and 10 gp worth of materials to construct a Tiny clockwork device (AC 5, 1 hp). The device ceases to function after 24 hours (unless you spend 1 hour repairing it to keep the device functioning), or when you use your action to dismantle it; at that time, you can reclaim the materials used to create it. You can have up to three such devices active at a time.
When you create a device, choose one of the following options:

entries.name: Clockwork Toy
entries: This toy is a clockwork animal, monster, or person, such as a frog, mouse, bird, dragon, or soldier. When placed on the ground, the toy moves 5 feet across the ground on each of your turns in a random direction. It makes noises as appropriate to the creature it represents.

entries.name: Fire Starter
entries: The device produces a miniature flame, which you can use to light a candle, torch, or campfire. Using the device requires your action.

entries.name: Music Box
entries: When opened, this music box plays a single song at a moderate volume. The box stops playing when it reaches the song’s end or when it is closed.

The diminutive little people, gnomes live below ground and guard their homeland with a jealous secrecy that few have glimpsed. Their dealings with the civilizations above ground is limited to trade, where they are known for intricate craftsmanship and ingenious devices. Some gnomes have come to live on the surface and assimilate to human life - known as halflings - as in half-humans.

The gnomes are masters of the tea ceremony, and it is rare to find even a halfling on the surface who does not travel with their tea set. While most are made of metal because of it’s durability, each tea set is handcrafted and unique to the person. Some are highly polished works of art, others are more functional in nature and so modified over the years by their user they more resemble some type of clockwork.

Gnomes of the Underdark are known to use their tea sets in communal rituals that allow them to {@spell Stone Shape} en masse. If enough gnomes participate in this ritual, they can effectively tunnel and travel through solid stone. The exact nature of this Stone Tea and it’s ceremony are a tightly guarded gnomish secret.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about {@link Rock Gnomes in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/gnome-rock-ARFvDASnZz}.

entries.name: Brisk Footed
entries: Your base walking speed is 30 feet. Your speed is not reduced by wearing heavy armor.

entries.name: Stone Marcher
entries: When you take the {@action Dash} action in mountainous or hilly environments, non-magical difficult terrain doesn't cost you extra movement on that turn.

The dwarves of the Kingdom's diaspora are collectively known as hearth dwarves. Wherever they have made their homes in the lands of Pyora, what separates them from their brethren is that they live their lives, raise families, and explore the world outside the influence of the current Prophet-King in Durandar.

Many are found in port towns, where they settled incidentally along migration routes. Others never left the sea, and pledge their lives to the hearthship of their confederates rather than follow the faithful underground. Some are outcasts or seekers - sorcerers and wizards who must search for arcane knowledge outside the unsupportive dwarven guild system.

They tend to follow dwarven customs in one way or another, mixed with the local flavor of wherever they find themselves. Just as many hold to the old prophecies as those who kneel to the new gods. These dwarves are fond of formalizing their chosen clans as businesses, settlements, communes, companies, and pirate ships - their 'hearths' - which more often than not include non-dwarves.

Despite their independent nature and varied experiences, whatever wanderlust drives them to seek fortune and community on their own also gives them a reputation for being fiercely loyal to those they choose for friends.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about {@link Hearth Dwarves in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/dwarf-hearth-JqwmFsdhFj}.

entries.name: Age
entries: Dwarves mature at the same rate as humans, but they're considered apprentices in Durandar until they reach the age of 100. On average, they live about 350 years.

entries.name: Durandian Ingenuity
entries: You are proficient in two {@item artisan's tools|phb}, due to the Kingdom's emphasize on craft and trades. You may alternately choose one {@item musical instrument|phb} to be proficient instead.

entries.name: Kingdom Training
entries: All dwarves in the kingdom are trained in basic martial arts. You have proficiency with the {@item battleaxe|phb}, {@item handaxe|phb}, {@item light hammer|phb}, and {@item warhammer}. You also have proficiency with light and medium armor.

It's taken centuries for {@link King Olfgard Wisebeard|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/king-olfgard-wisebeard-S0YDu9xGHy} to convince the majority of the dwarven tribes to abandon their homes and build the new granite city of {@link Durandar|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/durandar-sWDxZHDVIC} under the mountain. Opposed to the use of magic, the dwarves there dedicate themselves to alchemy & artificing, building great forges, damming the power of the rivers, and preparing for the apocalypse that's been foretold.

But dwarves are stubborn & not everyone has gone along. Some have stayed behind, adapting to the flood of newcomers to the old cities, while others have sought fortune on the continent as independent merchants or hireswords.
It is rumored that the pirates who plague {@link Striborg's merchant ships|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/striborg-navy-ndvIs6jZtX} are dwarves who prefer the open sea.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about {@link Dwarves in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/dwarf-durandian-UOdggQRi6Y}.

deity.name: Abraxas
deity.title: God of War
deity.symbol: Rooster whipping a dragon, Scale encircled by Whip
entries: God of war and martial classes, patron of {@link Iron Riders of Abraxas|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/iron-riders-of-abraxas-P77pTaxjou}, slayer of dragons. He is said to be the neutral arbiter of the other gods, instilling justice in the planes with his whip.
Many call on him to witness their oaths, in hope of currying his favor (and wrath) if the other party does not hold up their end.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about {@link Abraxas in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/abraxas-uKXAkU30vX}.

deity.name: Anhon
deity.title: God of the Sun
entries: This god of summer takes the form of a young man. He is inhumanly tall and has a wide-chested build. Anhon has short yellow hair, narrow brown eyes, and tan skin. He is usually portrayed as wearing a flattering costume that is mostly scarlet in color. Anhon wears a gold bracelet of intricate geometric design and carries a compass. Anhon is occasionally precocious with a neutral alignment.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about {@link Anhon in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/anhon-NB2cmmeCOh}.

deity.name: Azrael
deity.title: The Pathfinder
deity.symbol: Black Candle, Rainbows, Hooded Rider or Ferryman
entries: A hooded figure, wreathed in dark mist, carrying a scroll upon which the name of every living being is written at birth, a black candle floats behind its head, the spectral flame slowly cycling through every hue in the spectrum.

Sometimes appears as a rider atop a blindfolded stallion the color of the void, other times as a ferryman guiding a barge constructed from the ribs of a giant, lashed together by slowly-writhing, oily sinew.

To look within the hood is to behold endless cosmos, a vision so terrible one can never again turn their gaze to anything else, as they join the Pathfinder on their final journey from this mortal realm, and their name is erased from its scroll.
Patron of scribes, alchemists and cupbearers, often associated with cats, owls, lost coins and cloudless nights.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about {@link Azrael in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/azrael-ENK1L9l9rm}.

deity.name: Ostara
deity.title: The Trickster
deity.symbol: Triangle, Hares, Things that come in Threes
entries: Goddess of the changing seasons who represents uncontrollable wild places, hedonistic pleasure, the weather, and the domain between reality and illusion. Ostara is predictably unreliable, a force for both good & evil that often comes too early or too late, and usually in the form of tricks or riddles.

As opposed to the orderly chaotic good of {@link Selune|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/selune-wFfmk6l5Ba} who controls the rhythm of the moon and tides in the night, Ostara is true chaos that straddles the line between dreams and the light of dawn - it’s never clear if her attention is for favor or for ill. Possibly, it’s both.

It is said in legends when she appears as a human (always just before dawn), she takes the form of an ageless blonde with a gossamer dress made from frost, riding either a hare or a nightingale, disappearing at first light.
A common superstition is: Seeing a hare or a nightingale on a journey is considered either a good or bad omen, depending on the circumstances.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about {@link Ostara in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/ostara-pPhCdlIg9G}.

deity.name: Proteus
deity.title: God of the Sea
entries: God of the seas who is said to hold the key to the ocean and thus power over all living things. His domain is the eternal, the ancient unknown, and stability - the rock lost sailors cling to. His beard is longer than time and changes shapes as often as the waves.

He is engaged in a never ending struggle with the cycle of the tides, as each night {@link Selune’s|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/selune-wFfmk6l5Ba} waves pull the oceans apart and and spread madness and change throughout the world.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about {@link Proteus in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/proteus-Apiz4CreFn}.

deity.name: Raven Queen
deity.title: Goddess of Death
entries: A deity who rules in the ethereal fey magic of the far planes.

The Raven Queen, a deity shrouded in mystery, presides over the moment of transition between life and death. Her followers believe she is the guardian of the line between the living and the dead, watching over all those souls who cross it’s boundary. In Pyora, she is often associated with bad omens or bad luck.

The Raven Queen was once a powerful sorceress whose jealousy led her to a fateful act against her lover, {@link Eve|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/eve-QQyGI5YbZc}. In a singular moment of possessive rage, she clipped Eve's wings, scattering the feathers across the planes where they transformed into the {@race Ravenfolk|dungeonchurch}.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about {@link the Raven Queen in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/raven-queen-95zkXkC4gg}.

deity.name: Selûne
deity.title: Mother of Madness
entries: Goddess of the moon. Hers was the moon's mysterious power, the heavenly force that governed the world's tides and a mother's reproductive cycles, caused lycanthropes to shift form, and drew one to the brink of madness, and back again.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about {@link Selune in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/selune-wFfmk6l5Ba}.

deity.name: Siduri
deity.title: The Beer Runner
entries: Siduri is often depicted as a dwarf with a warm, inviting demeanor and a flowing beard adorned with jewels and hop vines, which are sacred to her. Their attire is vibrant and ever-changing, reflecting her fluid identity and the transformative nature of their domain.

In dwarven legends, Siduri was a crafty revolutionary who attempted a failed coup against the King. Imprisoned and waiting to be put to death, they escaped when the guards drank too much ale and fell asleep. Cursed to be on the run for eternity, Siduri grew a beard and changes identities to keep ahead of fate.

Siduri governs over fermentation, revelry, transformation, and joy. They are the patron of brewers, vintners, artists, thieves, and all who seek the joyful liberation found in festive gatherings or revolutions. Their name is invoked to ensure the success of crops used in brewing, the battle cries of rebels, and blessed as the host of many a joyful gathering.

Siduri’s most fervent followers are known to devote themselves to revolutionary causes of any and all types, no matter the grievance. A large part of their worship is organizing surreal parties, spontaneous parades, and theater troupes that transgress the taboo and occasionally veer into riots. For this reason, their temples and chapels are often persecuted or banned in large cities - widely seen as dangerous front groups for radical elements.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: Amelia's spellcasting attribute is Charisma (save {@dc 19}, {@hit 12} to hit with spell attacks). She can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

trait.name: Bend Fate (3/Day)
entries: If Amelia fails a saving throw, she may choose to succeed instead and reflect the effect of the failed saving throw onto one enemy within 30 feet. Amelia still suffers the effect of a successful saving throw, if any. The new target is entitled to a saving throw as if it were the original target of the attack, but with disadvantage.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: Amelia has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Misty Step (At Will)
entries: Amelia can step between places as a bonus action.

trait.name: Sealed Destiny (1/Day)
entries: Amelia attunes herself to the threads of the PCs' fates. Ask each player to write down their prediction of how the PC to their left will die, and at what level. Collect the notes without revealing the answers. When one of those PCs dies, reveal the prediction. If the character died in the manner predicted, they fulfill their destiny and are immediately resurrected by the gods as a reward. If they died at or within one level of the prediction, they return to life with some useful insight into the destiny of someone important.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: Amelia makes two Inexorable Thread attacks.

action.name: Inexorable Threads
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 9} to hit, reach 30 ft., one target. {@h}27 ({@damage 5d8 + 5}) radiant damage, and the target is "one step closer to death." If the target is reduced to 0 hit points, it's treated as if it's already failed one death saving throw. This effect is cumulative; each inexorable threads hit adds one unsuccessful death saving throw. If a character who's been hit three or more times by inexorable threads is reduced to 0 hit points, he or she dies immediately. This effect lasts until the character completes a long rest.

action.name: Bind Fates (1/Day)
entries: One target within 60 feet of Amelia must make a {@dc 18} Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, the target's fate is bound to one random ally of the target. Any damage or condition the target suffers is inflicted on the individual to which they are bound instead, and vice versa. A creature can be bound to only one other creature at a time. This effect lasts until either of the affected creatures gains a level, or until a heal or heroes' feast lifts this binding.

action.name: Destiny Distortion Wave {@recharge 5}
entries: Amelia projects a 60-foot cone of distortion that frays the strands of fate. All targets in the cone take 55 ({@damage 10d10}) force damage, or half damage with a successful {@dc 18} Wisdom saving throw. In addition, if more than one target that failed its saving throw is affected by a condition, those conditions are randomly redistributed among the targets with failed saving throws.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about the {@link Amelia in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/amelia-mAibH1T0Em}.

trait.name: False Appearance
entries: While the briar tree remains motionless, it is indistinguishable from a normal tree.

trait.name: Thorny Defense
entries: A creature that touches the briar tree or hits it with a melee attack while within 5 feet of it takes 5 ({@dice 2d4}) piercing damage.

action.name: Slam
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}14 ({@damage 3d6 + 4}) bludgeoning damage.

trait.name: Lightning Absoprtion
entries: Whenever the briar mound would take lightning damage, it instead takes no damage and regains hit points equal to the damage dealt.

trait.name: Thorny Defense
entries: A creature that touches the briar mound or hits it with a melee attack while within 5 feet of it takes 5 ({@dice 2d4}) piercing damage.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The briar mound makes two attacks.

action.name: Slam
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}14 ({@damage 3d6 + 4}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Engulf
entries: The briar mound engulfs a Medium or smaller creature {@condition grappled} by it. The engulfed target is {@condition blinded}, {@condition restrained}, and unable to breathe, and it must succeed on a {@dc 14} saving throw at the start of each of the briar mound's turns or take 13 ({@damage 2d8 + 4}) bludgeoning damage. If the briar mound moves, the engulfed target moves with it. The briar mound can have only one creature engulfed at a time.

trait.name: Blood Frenzy
entries: The shark has advantage on melee attack rolls against any creature that doesn't have all its hit points.

trait.name: Construct Nature
entries: The clockwork shark doesn't require air, food, drink, or sleep.

trait.name: Immutable Form
entries: The clockwork shark is immune to any spell or effect that would alter its form.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The clockwork shark has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 0 ft, one target. {@h}17 ({@damage 5d6}) piercing damage plus 3 ({@damage 1d6}) force damage.

monster.name: Coal Golem

immune.note: from nonmagical attacks that aren't adamantine

languages: understands the languages of its creator but can't speak

trait.name: Ignite
entries: When the Coal Golem would take fire damage from any source, it is lit aflame for 1 minute. While set aflame it casts a bright light 20ft and dim light another 20ft. In addition, whenever a creature hits (or is hit by) the golem with a melee attack, they suffer {@damage 1d6} fire damage.

trait.name: Immutable Form
entries: The golem is immune to any spell or effect that would alter its form.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The golem has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Magic Weapons
entries: The golem's weapon attacks are magical.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The golem makes two slam attacks.

action.name: Slam
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 10} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}19 ({@damage 3d8 + 6}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Slow {@recharge 5}
entries: The golem targets one or more creatures it can see within 10 feet of it. Each target must make a {@dc 17} Wisdom saving throw against this magic. On a failed save, a target can't use reactions, its speed is halved, and it can't make more than one attack on its turn. In addition, the target can take either an action or a bonus action on its turn, not both. These effects last for 1 minute. A target can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

trait.name: Charge
entries: If the dire boar moves at least 20 feet straight toward a target and then hits it with a tusk attack on the same turn, the target takes an extra 7 ({@damage 2d6}) slashing damage. If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a {@dc 13} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}.

trait.name: Relentless (Recharges after a Short or Long Rest)
entries: If the dire boar takes 10 damage or less that would reduce it to 0 hit points, it is reduced to 1 hit point instead.

trait.name: Survival Instinct
entries: The dire boar has advantage on Survival (Wisdom) checks.

trait.name: Blood Frenzy
entries: The dire boar has advantage on melee attack rolls against any creature that doesn't have all its hit points

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The dire boar makes two attacks with it's tusks.

action.name: Tusk
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 2d6}) slashing damage.

trait.name: Escape
entries: The dire hare can take the Dash, Disengage, or Hide action as a bonus action on each of its turns.

trait.name: Keen Hearing
entries: The dire hare has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on hearing.

trait.name: Charge
entries: If the dire hare moves at least 20 feet straight toward a target and then hits it with its bite on the same turn, the target takes an extra 7 ({@dice 2d6}) piercing damage. If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a {@dc 13} Dexterity saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}.

reaction.name: Infestation
entries: If the dire hare is hit with a melee attack, all creatures within 5 ft. of the hare must make a {@dc 13} Dexterity saving throw or they are covered with a {@creature Swarm of Insects|mm|Swarm of Fleas}.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +2} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}3 ({@damage 1d6}) piercing damage. If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a {@dc 11} saving throw against disease or become {@condition poisoned}

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: Commodore Daniel is a 12th-level spellcaster. His spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 15}). The Commodore has the following pspells prepared:

trait.name: Aura of Clarity (Human Form)
entries: While within 10 feet of a conscious Commodore Daniel, creatures of the Commodore's choice can't be {@condition blinded} or {@condition frightened}, and creatures and objects can be {@condition invisible} only if the commodore allows it.

trait.name: Brand Heretic (Recharges after a Short or Long Rest)
entries: As a bonus action, the Commodore Daniel chooses one creature the Commodore can see within 30 feet of it. The Commodore marks the target as a heretic. For 1 minute, the Commodore's weapon attack rolls against the heretic score a critical hit on a roll of 19 or 20. At the start of each of the heretic's turns, the Commodore can use a reaction to make one weapon attack against the heretic.

trait.name: Smite
entries: When Commodore Daniel hits with a melee weapon attack, it can expend one spell slot to deal extra radiant damage. The extra damage is 9 ({@dice 2d8}) for a 1st level spell slot, 13 ({@dice 3d8}) for a 2nd-level one, and 18 ({@dice 4d8}) for a 3rd level slot.

trait.name: Shapechanger
entries: As an action, Commodore Daniel can polymorph into one of his lycanthrope forms: a boar-humanoid hybrid or a {@creature Boar}. While in lycanthrope form, the wereboar gains resistance to bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage from non-silvered, non-magical sources. Any equipment he is wearing or carrying isn't transformed. He reverts to its true form if he dies.

trait.name: Charge (Lycanthrope Form)
entries: If the wereboar moves at least 15 feet straight toward a target and then hits it with its tusks on the same turn, the target takes an extra 7 ({@dice 2d6}) slashing damage. If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a {@dc 13} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}.

trait.name: Lust for the Hunt (Lycanthrope Form)
entries: The savage nature of your curse causes you to lose control. When in hybrid form, make a {@dc 12} Wisdom saving throw at the beginning of each turn. On a fail, the wereboar is overcome with bloodlust and attacks the nearest creature, or dashes towards the nearest helpless or weak creature.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The Commodore makes two attacks, only one of which can be with his tusks if in hybrid form.

action.name: Greatsword
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}11 ({@damage 2d6 + 4}) slashing damage and 4 ({@damage 1d8}) radiant damage.

action.name: Maul (Lycanthrope Form)
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}11 ({@damage 2d6 + 4}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Tusks (Lycanthrope Form)
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +5} to hit, reach ft., one target. {@h}10 ({@damage 2d6+3}) slashing damage. If the target is a humanoid, it must succeed on a {@dc 12} Constitution saving throw or be cursed with wereboar lycanthropy.

entries.name: Lust for Vengeance
entries: His {@link father|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/commodore-wardell-warrington-JVLIYKxGXE} the former Commodore was {@link killed aboard|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/session-15-16-murder-on-the-jubilee-b5dYJiJkGZ} the Dragon's Jubilee by the vampire {@creature Lamont Solmar, Knight of Night|dungeonchurch|Lamont Solmar}. The young Lieutenant became the new Commodore, bent on avenging his father’s death. He has consolidated control of security forces after the {@creature sahuagin} attack, and taken over what was left of the {@link Saltmarsh Town Guard|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/saltmarsh-town-guard-v63eLpRU1Q} and thus gaining himself a seat on the {@link Saltmarsh Council|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/saltmarsh-council-8KxfpMfTQ0}.

entries.name: Curse of Lycanthropy
entries: During a {@link brazen assault |https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/the-ladys-price-9GqAM1W0Pw} on his mansion by monsters directed by Lady Nightshade, Daniel was dosed with {@item Nightshade Poison|dungeonchurch}, transforming him into a {@creature wereboar} lycanthrope.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about {@link Commodore Daniel Warrington in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/commodore-daniel-warrington-OHzOMkhMHS}.

trait.name: Ignite
entries: When the Giant Coal Ant would take fire damage from any source, it is lit aflame for 1 minute. While set aflame it casts a bright light 20ft and dim light another 20ft. In addition, whenever a creature hits (or is hit by) the ant with a melee attack, they suffer {@damage 1d6} fire damage.

trait.name: Keen Smell
entries: The giant ant has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on smell.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The giant ant makes one Bite attack and one Sting attack.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d8 + 2}) bludgeoning damage, and the target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 12}). Until this grapple ends, the target is {@condition restrained}, and the giant ant can't Bite a different target.

action.name: Sting
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d8 + 2}) piercing damage. The target must make a {@dc 12} Constitution saving throw, taking 11 ({@damage 2d10}) poison damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about the {@link Giant Coal Ant in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/giant-coal-ant-M9repJEaQW}.

resist.note: from nonmagical attacks that aren't silvered

trait.name: Devil's Sight
entries: Magical darkness doesn't impede the hellion's darkvision.

trait.name: Flyby
entries: The hellion doesn't provoke an opportunity attack when it flies out of an enemy's reach.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The hellion has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The hellion makes two attacks: one with its bite and one with its fork

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 2} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 2d4}) slashing damage.

action.name: Fork
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 2} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}3 ({@damage 1d6}) piercing damage.

action.name: Rebellious Tongue
entries: If the hellion did not Bite this turn, it may use {@spell Vicious Mockery}.

entries.name: Tormented Souls
entries: Hellions are the souls of children who died in torment or agony and are unable to move on from this plane. Bound by a seething, confused hatred to the places where they perished they spend their days looking for humans to endlessly torture with their vicious mockery.

entries.name: Easily Influenced
entries: Due to their undeveloped personalities, their childlike tantrums lead them to lash out at the world without rhyme or reason. This same temperament makes them easily susceptible to the influence of any figure presenting themselves as a parental figure - especially sorcerers, warlocks, and wizards who channel the rage of these fickle fiends.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about the {@link Hellion Children in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/hellion-child-cmTM1BgZSd}.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The Iron Rider Deputy is a 1st-level spellcaster. Its spellcasting ability is Charisma. The deputy knows the following spell:

trait.name: Iron Rider's Authority
entries: The Iron Rider Deputy can expend a 1st-level ranger spell slot to imbue themselves with the authority of their station for 1 minute. They gain advantage on any check related to leadership, persuasion, or intimidation.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The Iron Rider Deputy makes two shortsword attacks, provided it has a {@item shortsword|PHB} in each hand.

action.name: Shortsword
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}3 ({@damage 1d4 + 1}) piercing damage, or 2 ({@damage 1d4}) psychic damage if the target is {@status concentration||concentrating} on a spell.

action.name: Longbow
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 4} to hit, ranged 150/600 ft., one target. {@h}3 ({@damage 1d4 + 1}) piercing damage, or 2 ({@damage 1d4}) psychic damage if the target is {@status concentration||concentrating} on a spell.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about the {@link Iron Rider Deputy in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/iron-rider-deputy-S9G0VKvtRB}.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The Iron Rider hunter is a 3rd-level spellcaster. Its spellcasting ability is Wisdom. The hunter knows the following ranger spells:

trait.name: Iron Rider's Awareness
entries: The Iron Rider hunter can expend a 1st-level ranger spell slot to sense for 1 minute whether arcane or innate spellcasters, aberrations, fey, and fiends are within 1 mile. This trait doesn't reveal the creatures' locations or numbers.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The Iron Rider hunter makes two shortsword attacks, provided it has a {@item shortsword|PHB} in each hand.

action.name: Shortsword
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d6 + 2}) piercing damage and 2 ({@damage 1d4}) psychic damage, or 5 ({@damage 2d4}) psychic damage if the target is {@status concentration||concentrating} on a spell.

action.name: Longbow
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 4} to hit, ranged 150/600 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d8 + 2}) piercing damage and 2 ({@damage 1d4}) psychic damage, or 5 ({@damage 2d4}) psychic damage if the target is {@status concentration||concentrating} on a spell.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about the {@link Iron Rider Hunter in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/iron-rider-hunter-kPxugCHSLi}.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The Iron Rider Commodore is a 12th-level spellcaster. Its spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 14}). The commodore has the following paladin spells prepared:

trait.name: Aura of Clarity
entries: While within 10 feet of a conscious Iron Rider commodore, creatures of the commodore's choice can't be {@condition blinded} or {@condition frightened}, and creatures and objects can be {@condition invisible} only if the commodore allows it.

trait.name: Brand Heretic (Recharges after a Short or Long Rest)
entries: As a bonus action, the Iron Rider commodore chooses one creature the commodore can see within 30 feet of it. The commodore marks the target as a heretic. For 1 minute, the commodore's weapon attack rolls against the heretic score a critical hit on a roll of 19 or 20. At the start of each of the heretic's turns, the commodore can use a reaction to make one weapon attack against the heretic.

trait.name: Smite
entries: When the Iron Rider commodore hits with a melee weapon attack, it can expend one spell slot to deal extra radiant damage. The extra damage is 9 ({@dice 2d8}) for a 1stlevel spell slot, 13 ({@dice 3d8}) for a 2nd-level one, and 18 ({@dice 4d8}) for a 3rd level slot.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The commodore makes two greatsword attacks.

action.name: Greatsword
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}11 ({@damage 2d6 + 4}) slashing damage and 4 ({@damage 1d8}) radiant damage.

trait.name: Brave
entries: The Iron Rider knight has advantage on saving throws against being {@condition frightened}.

trait.name: Discerning
entries: The Iron Rider knight has advantage on saving throws against illusions.

trait.name: Mark
entries: When the Iron Rider knight hits a creature with a melee weapon attack, the knight marks that creature until the end of the knight's next turn. The mark ends early if the knight becomes {@condition incapacitated} or dies, or someone else marks the same creature. While the marked creature is within the knight's reach, it has disadvantage on attack rolls against creatures other than the knight.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The Iron Rider knight makes two attacks.

action.name: Longsword
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d8 + 3}) slashing damage, or 8 ({@damage 1d10 + 3}) slashing damage if used with two hands to make a melee attack, and Mark.

action.name: Javelin
entries: {@atk mw,rw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft. or range 30/120 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d6 + 3}) piercing damage and, if used to make a melee attack, and Mark.

reaction.name: Marked Control
entries: If a creature subjected to the Iron Rider knight's Mark moves while within 5 feet of the knight, the knight can make a melee attack against that creature. On a hit, the creature's speed drops to 0 until the end of their current turn.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about the {@link Iron Rider Deputy in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/iron-rider-knight-JIpk2Tegm7}.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The Iron Rider priest is a 6th-level spellcaster. Its spellcasting ability is Wisdom (spell save {@dc 13}, {@hit 5} to hit with spell attacks). It has the following cleric spells prepared:

trait.name: Ward
entries: If the Iron Rider priest casts a spell that causes creatures to regain hit points, the priest can also end the effects of one spell affecting one creature that regained hit points. The ended effects must be from a spell of a level equal to or lower than the spell slot the priest used to cast the healing spell.

action.name: Warhammer
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 3} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d8 + 1}) bludgeoning damage and 4 ({@damage 1d8}) force damage, or 9 ({@damage 2d8}) force damage if the target is {@status concentration||concentrating} on a spell.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about the {@link Iron Rider Priest in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/iron-rider-priest-rqFdIU3jmX}.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The Iron Rider warder is a 12th-level spellcaster. Its spellcasting ability is Wisdom (spell save {@dc 15}, {@hit 7} to hit with spell attacks). It has the following cleric spells prepared:

trait.name: Ward
entries: If the Iron Rider warder casts a spell that causes creatures to regain hit points, the warder can also end the effects of one spell affecting one creature that regained hit points. The ended effects must be from a spell of a level equal to or lower than the spell slot the warder used to cast the healing spell.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The Iron Rider warder makes two warhammer attacks.

action.name: Warhammer
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d8 + 3}) bludgeoning damage and 9 ({@damage 2d8}) force damage, or 13 ({@damage 3d8}) force damage if the target is {@status concentration||concentrating} on a spell.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about the {@link Iron Rider Warder in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/iron-rider-warder-TQ0pXTDXj0}.

trait.name: Fey Blood
entries: King Thistletongue counts as both plant and fey for any effect related to type.

trait.name: Nimble Escape
entries: King Thistletongue can take the {@action Disengage} or {@action Hide} action as a bonus action on each of its turns.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: King Thistletongue makes two claw attacks. If both attacks hit the same target, the target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 16}) and the King uses its Thorny Grapple on it.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 9} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}36 ({@damage 9d6 + 5}) piercing damage.

action.name: Spitdart Tongue {@recharge 4}
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 9} to hit, range 20/60 ft., one target. {@h}36 ({@damage 9d6 + 5}) piercing damage.King Thistletongue can shoot thorns from its mouth.

action.name: Entangle
entries: Two children of the briar working together can cast a version of the entangle spell with no components, at will. Both creatures must be within 10 feet of each other, and both must use their action to cast the spell. The entangled area must include at least one of the casters but doesn't need to be centered on either caster. Creatures in the area must make a {@dc 16} Strength saving throw or be {@condition restrained}. All children of the briar are immune to the spell's effects.

action.name: Thorny Grapple
entries: King Thistletongue's long thorny limbs help it grapple creatures up to Medium size. A {@condition grappled} creature takes 12 ({@damage 5d4}) piercing damage at the end of the child's turn for as long as it remains {@condition grappled}.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: King Thistletongue's spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 14}). He can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

entries.name: Born of Magic
entries: Children of the briar are a frequent nuisance to fey and mortal alike. They grow in deep briar patches in forest clearings or along sunny hillsides and riverbanks. More rarely, they spawn when a sorcerer or magical creature's blood is spilled on the forest floor, or when summoned into being by obscure druidic items of power.

entries.name: Thorn Fortresses
entries: Despite their size, children of the briar gather in great numbers, cultivating ancient forest thickets into veritable fortresses. Wise men flee when they hear their clicking language in the underbrush, for the children have all the capricious wickedness of spiteful children and a taste for blood.

entries.name: Spies and Scouts
entries: From their lairs, the children of the briar creep far and wide to spy on the forest's inhabitants, sometimes using spiders, monstrous centipedes, and giant dragonflies as mounts. They converse with travelers bearing interesting news, but their words are thorned with gleeful malice, jealous bile, and lies. They are not above murder. They trade news and gossip for trinkets, favors, and drops of spilled blood.

The fey have long used the children of the briar as spies and informants, and the power of the Otherworld now courses through their veins, allowing them to work simple magical tricks and slip between the mortal and faerie realms with relative ease.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about {@link King Thistletongue in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/king-thistletongue-byqTEswqZE}.

trait.name: Shapechanger
entries: If the vampire isn't in sunlight or running water, it can use its action to polymorph into a Tiny bat or a Medium cloud of mist, or into their true form.

While in bat form, the vampire can't speak, its walking speed is 5 feet, and it has a flying speed of 30 feet. Its statistics, other than its size and speed, are unchanged. Anything it is wearing transforms with it, but nothing it is carrying does. It reverts to its true form if it dies.

While in mist form, the vampire can't take any actions, speak, or manipulate objects. It is weightless, has a flying speed of 20 feet, can hover, and can enter a hostile creature's space and stop there. In addition, if air can pass through a space, the mist can do so without squeezing, and it can't pass through water. It has advantage on Strength, Dexterity, and Constitution saving throws, and it is immune to all nonmagical damage, except the damage it takes from sunlight.

trait.name: Saltmarsh Spy
entries: Lamont keeps an eye on the town he knew and loved in life, including his living son {@link Anders|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/anders-solmor-njTKn6ITMV}. Whenever Lamont visits {@link Saltmarsh|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/saltmarsh-GkGI6ISio5} after dark, he is able to shapechange into the form of any of his vampire thralls.

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (3/Day)
entries: If the vampire fails a saving throw, it can choose to succeed instead.

trait.name: Misty Escape
entries: When it drops to 0 hit points outside its resting place, the vampire transforms into a cloud of mist (as in the Shapechanger trait) instead of falling {@condition unconscious}, provided that it isn't in sunlight or running water. If it can't transform, it is destroyed.

While it has 0 hit points in mist form, it can't revert to its vampire form, and it must reach its resting place within 2 hours or be destroyed. Once in its resting place, it reverts to its vampire form. It is then {@condition paralyzed} until it regains at least 1 hit point. After spending 1 hour in its resting place with 0 hit points, it regains 1 hit point.

trait.name: Regeneration
entries: The vampire regains 20 hit points at the start of its turn if it has at least 1 hit point and isn't in sunlight or running water. If the vampire takes radiant damage or damage from holy water, this trait doesn't function at the start of the vampire's next turn.

trait.name: Spider Climb
entries: The vampire can climb difficult surfaces, including upside down on ceilings, without needing to make an ability check.

trait.name: Vampire Weaknesses
entries: The vampire has the following flaws:
{@i Forbiddance.} The vampire can't enter a residence without an invitation from one of the occupants.
{@i Harmed by Running Water.} The vampire takes 20 acid damage if it ends its turn in running water.

{@i Stake to the Heart.} If a piercing weapon made of wood is driven into the vampire's heart while the vampire is {@condition incapacitated} in its resting place, the vampire is {@condition paralyzed} until the stake is removed.
{@i Sunlight Hypersensitivity.} The vampire takes 20 radiant damage when it starts its turn in sunlight. While in sunlight, it has disadvantage on attack rolls and ability checks.

action.name: Multiattack (Vampire Form Only)
entries: The vampire makes two attacks, only one of which can be a bite attack.

action.name: Unarmed Strike (Vampire Form Only)
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 9} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. {@h}8 ({@damage 1d8 + 4}) bludgeoning damage. Instead of dealing damage, the vampire can grapple the target (escape {@dc 18}).

action.name: Bite (Bat or Vampire Form Only)
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 9} to hit, reach 5 ft., one willing creature, or a creature that is {@condition grappled} by the vampire, {@condition incapacitated}, or {@condition restrained}. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d6 + 4}) piercing damage plus 10 ({@damage 3d6}) necrotic damage. The target's hit point maximum is reduced by an amount equal to the necrotic damage taken, and the vampire regains hit points equal to that amount. The reduction lasts until the target finishes a long rest. The target dies if this effect reduces its hit point maximum to 0. A humanoid slain in this way and then buried in the ground rises the following night as a {@creature vampire spawn} under the vampire's control.

action.name: Charm
entries: The vampire targets one humanoid it can see within 30 feet of it. If the target can see the vampire, the target must succeed on a {@dc 17} Wisdom saving throw against this magic or be {@condition charmed} by the vampire. The {@condition charmed} target regards the vampire as a trusted friend to be heeded and protected. Although the target isn't under the vampire's control, it takes the vampire's requests or actions in the most favorable way it can, and it is a willing target for the vampire's bite attack.

Each time the vampire or the vampire's companions do anything harmful to the target, it can repeat the saving throw, ending the effect on itself on a success. Otherwise, the effect lasts 24 hours or until the vampire is destroyed, is on a different plane of existence than the target, or takes a bonus action to end the effect.

action.name: Children of the Night (1/Day)
entries: The vampire magically calls {@dice 2d4} swarms of {@creature swarm of bats||bats} or {@creature swarm of rats||rats}, provided that the sun isn't up. While outdoors, the vampire can call {@dice 3d6} {@creature wolf||wolves} instead. The called creatures arrive in {@dice 1d4} rounds, acting as allies of the vampire and obeying its spoken commands. The beasts remain for 1 hour, until the vampire dies, or until the vampire dismisses them as a bonus action.

legendary.name: Move
entries: The vampire moves up to its speed without provoking opportunity attacks.

legendary.name: Unarmed Strike
entries: The vampire makes one unarmed strike.

legendary.name: Bite (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: The vampire makes one bite attack.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about the {@link Lamont Solmar in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/lamont-solmar-GLrWBoIX5h}.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The hag's innate spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 14}). She can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

trait.name: Amphibious
entries: The hag can breathe air and water.

trait.name: Mimicry
entries: The hag can mimic animal sounds and humanoid voices. A creature that hears the sounds can tell they are imitations with a successful {@dc 16} Wisdom ({@skill Insight}) check.

action.name: Claws
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}23 ({@damage 4d8 + 5}) slashing damage.

action.name: Illusory Appearance
entries: The hag covers herself and anything she is wearing or carrying with a magical illusion that makes her look like another creature of her general size and humanoid shape. The illusion ends if the hag takes a bonus action to end it or if she dies.

The changes wrought by this effect fail to hold up to physical inspection. For example, the hag could appear to have smooth skin, but someone touching her would feel her rough flesh. Otherwise, a creature must take an action to visually inspect the illusion and succeed on a {@dc 22} Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) check to discern that the hag is disguised.

action.name: Invisible Passage
entries: The hag magically turns {@condition invisible} until she attacks or casts a spell, or until her {@status concentration} ends (as if {@status concentration||concentrating} on a spell). While {@condition invisible}, she leaves no physical evidence of her passage, so she can be tracked only by magic. Any equipment she wears or carries is {@condition invisible} with her.

The wretched and hateful green hags dwell in dying forests, lonely swamps, and misty moors, making their homes in caves. Green hags love to manipulate other creatures into doing their bidding, masking their intentions behind layers of deception. They lure victims to them by mimicking voices calling out for help, or drive unwanted visitors away by imitating the cries of fierce beasts.

entries.name: Obsession with Tragedy
entries: Green hags revel in the failings and tragedies of other creatures. They derive joy from bringing people low and seeing hope turn into despair, not just for individuals but also for whole nations.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about {@link Mildred Magpie in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/mildred-magpie-y6vemFK5Bi}.

entries.name: Hags
entries: Hags represent all that is evil and cruel. Though they resemble withered crones, there is nothing mortal about these monstrous creatures, whose forms reflect only the wickedness in their hearts.

entries.name: Faces of Evil
entries: Ancient beings with origins in the Feywild, hags are cankers on the mortal world. Their withered faces are framed by long, frayed hair, horrid moles and warts dot their blotchy skin, and their long, skinny fingers are tipped by claws that can slice open flesh with a touch. Their simple clothes are always tattered and filthy.

All hags possess magical powers, and some have an affinity for spellcasting. They can alter their forms or curse their foes, and their arrogance inspires them to view their magic as a challenge to the magic of the gods, whom they blaspheme at every opportunity.
Hags name themselves in darkly whimsical ways, claiming monikers such as Black Morwen, Peggy Pigknuckle, Grandmother Titchwillow, Nanna Shug, Rotten Ethel, or Auntie Wormtooth.

entries.name: Monstrous Motherhood
entries: Hags propagate by snatching and devouring human infants. After stealing a baby from its cradle or its mother's womb, the hag consumes the poor child. A week later, the hag gives birth to a daughter who looks human until her thirteenth birthday, whereupon the child transforms into the spitting image of her hag mother.
Hags sometimes raise the daughters they spawn, creating covens. A hag might also return the child to its grieving parents, only to watch from the shadows as the child grows up to become a horror.

entries.name: Dark Bargains
entries: Arrogant to a fault, hags believe themselves to be the most cunning of creatures, and they treat all others as inferior. Even so, a hag is open to dealing with mortals as long as those mortals show the proper respect and deference. Over their long lives, hags accumulate much knowledge of local lore, dark creatures, and magic, which they are pleased to sell.

Hags enjoy watching mortals bring about their own downfall, and a bargain with a hag is always dangerous. The terms of such bargains typically involve demands to compromise principles or give up something dear-especially if the thing lost diminishes or negates the knowledge gained through the bargain.

entries.name: A Foul Nature
entries: Hags love the macabre and festoon their garb with dead things and accentuate their appearance with bones, bits of flesh, and filth. They nurture blemishes and pick at wounds to produce weeping, suppurating flesh. Attractive creatures evoke disgust in a hag, which might "help" such creatures by disfiguring or transforming them.

This embrace of the disturbing and unpleasant extends to all aspects of a hag's life. A hag might fly in a magical giant's skull, landing it on a tree shaped to resemble an enormous headless body. Another might travel with a menagerie of monsters and slaves kept in cages, and disguised by illusions to lure unwary creatures close. Hags sharpen their teeth on millstones and spin cloth from the intestines of their victims, reacting with glee to the horror their actions invoke.

entries.name: Dark Sorority
entries: Hags maintain contact with each other and share knowledge. Through such contacts, it is likely that any given hag knows of every other hag in existence. Hags don't like each other, but they abide by an ageless code of conduct. Hags announce their presence before crossing into another hag's territory, bring gifts when entering another hag's dwelling, and break no oaths given to other hags-as long as the oath isn't given with the fingers crossed.

Some humanoids make the mistake of thinking that the hags' rules of conduct apply to all creatures. When confronted by such an individual, a hag might find it amusing to string the fool along for a while before teaching it a permanent lesson.

entries.name: Dark Lairs
entries: Hags dwell in dark and twisted woods, bleak moors, storm-lashed seacoasts, and gloomy swamps. In time, the landscape around a hag's lair reflects the creature's noxiousness, such that the land itself can attack and kill trespassers. Trees twisted by darkness attack passersby, while vines snake through the undergrowth to snare and drag off creatures one at a time. Foul stinking fogs turn the air to poison, and conceal pools of quicksand and sinkholes that consume unwary wanderers.

entries.name: Hag Covens
entries: When hags must work together, they form covens, in spite of their selfish natures. A coven is made up of hags of any type, all of whom are equals within the group. However, each of the hags continues to desire more personal power.

A coven consists of three hags so that any arguments between two hags can be settled by the third. If more than three hags ever come together, as might happen if two covens come into conflict, the result is usually chaos.

entries.name: Shared Spellcasting
entries: While all three members of a hag coven are within 30 feet of one another, they can each cast the following spells from the wizard's spell list but must share the spell slots among themselves:

items: 1st level (4 slots): {@spell identify}, {@spell ray of sickness}
2nd level (3 slots): {@spell hold person}, {@spell locate object}
3rd level (3 slots): {@spell bestow curse}, {@spell counterspell}, {@spell lightning bolt}
5th level (2 slots): {@spell contact other plane}, {@spell scrying}

entries: For casting these spells, each hag is a 12th-level spellcaster that uses Intelligence as her spellcasting ability. The spell save DC is 12 + the hag's Intelligence modifier, and the spell attack bonus is 4 + the hag's Intelligence modifier.

entries.name: Hag Eye
entries: A hag coven can craft a magic item called a hag eye, which is made from a real eye coated in varnish and often fitted to a pendant or other wearable item. The hag eye is usually entrusted to a minion for safekeeping and transport. A hag in the coven can take an action to see what the hag eye sees if the hag eye is on the same plane of existence. A hag eye has AC 10, 1 hit point, and {@sense darkvision} with a radius of 60 feet. If it is destroyed, each coven member takes {@damage 3d10} psychic damage and is {@condition blinded} for 24 hours.

A hag coven can have only one hag eye at a time, and creating a new one requires all three members of the coven to perform a ritual. The ritual takes 1 hour, and the hags can't perform it while {@condition blinded}. During the ritual, if the hags take any action other than performing the ritual, they must start over.

entries.name: Lair Actions
entries: The following lair actions are options for grandmothers and powerful aunties. Grandmothers usually have three to five lair actions, aunties usually only one (if they have any at all). Unless otherwise noted, any lair action that requires a creature to make a saving throw uses the save DC of the hag's most powerful ability.
On initiative count 20 (losing initiative ties), the hag can take a lair action to cause one of the following effects, but can't use the same effect two rounds in a row:

items: Until initiative count 20 on the next round, the hag can pass through solid walls, doors, ceilings, and floors as if the surfaces weren't there.

The hag targets any number of doors and windows that she can see, causing each one to either open or close as she wishes. Closed doors can be magically locked (requiring a successful {@dc 20} Strength check to force open) until she chooses to make them unlocked, or until she uses this lair action again to open them.

entries: A powerful green hag might have the following additional lair action:

items: The hag creates an illusory duplicate of herself, which appears in its own space. As long as she can see her duplicate, the hag can move it a distance equal to her walking speed as well as make the illusion speak on her turn (no action required). The illusion has the same statistics as the hag but can't take actions or reactions. It can interact with its environment and even pick up and hold real objects. The illusion seems real in every way but disappears if it takes any amount of damage. Otherwise, it lasts until the hag dismisses it (no action required) or can no longer see it. If the hag uses this lair action to create a new duplicate, the previous one vanishes, dropping any real objects in its possession.

monster.name: Sap Ooze
languages: none in its natural form; knows the same languages as a creature it dominates

trait.name: Amorphous
entries: The sap ooze can move through a space as narrow as 1 inch wide without squeezing.

trait.name: Season's Change
entries: If a sap ooze (or its host) takes at least 10 fire damage, it also gains the effect of a {@spell haste} spell until the end of its next turn. If it takes at least 10 cold damage, it gains the effect of a {@spell slow} spell until the end of its next turn.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The sap ooze makes two slam attacks.

action.name: Slam
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}11 ({@damage 2d8 + 2}) bludgeoning damage. If both attacks hit a Medium or smaller target, the target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 12}), and the sap ooze uses Soul Sap on it as a bonus action.

action.name: Soul Sap
entries: The sap ooze slides down the throat of a sleeping, helpless, or {@condition grappled} living creature of Medium size or smaller. Once inside, the sap ooze takes control of its host, as per the dominate monster spell (Wisdom {@dc 12} negates). While dominated, the host gains {@sense blindsight} 90 feet. The host drips blood from its ears, nose, eyes, or from a wound that resembles the injury done to the sap demon's tree (1 damage/Hour). Damage inflicted on the host has no effect on the sap demon.
