If the host dies or is reduced to 0 hit points, the sap ooze must leave the body within one hour.

{@i When a sap ooze leaves a tree, its milky amber fluid oozes from an axe wound on a stout maple's trunk and shapes itself into a small, vaguely humanoid form on the forest floor beside the tree. This languid creature half walks and half flows forward, implacably following the axe wielder's path to certain revenge.}

entries.name: Tree Oozes
entries: Sap oozes are intelligent oozes that form when an enchanted tree is cut or injured. Though typically Small, the larger the sap source is, the larger the resulting creature can be. Over a few hours, they pool into a shape that vaguely resembles their tree's attacker: for instance, if the tree cutter wore a hat, then a hat may be incorporated into the sap ooze's overall shape. The similarity is faint at best; no one would ever confuse a sap ooze for the creature it hunts, because its shape has no sharp features or color other than amber.

entries.name: Called to Vengeance
entries: Sap oozes can pummel their prey with partially-crystallized fists, but they especially enjoy claiming the weapon that wounded their tree and wielding it to deliver a final blow. Once their prey is destroyed, most sap oozes return to their tree, but not all do. Some are curious or malevolent enough to explore the world further.

entries.name: Reckless Possessors
entries: A sap ooze can possess another creature by grappling it and oozing down its throat. Once inside, the sap ooze dominates its host and makes it bleed as the tree bled. Since the sap ooze takes no damage when its host is wounded, it's free to be as reckless as it likes. It might wander into a town to cause trouble. However, no matter how its new body is bandaged or cured, it never stops bleeding slowly. If the host body is killed, the sap oozes out during the next hour and either returns to its tree or seeks another host.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about the {@link Sap Ooze in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/sap-ooze-eGVX8QPLEh}.

trait.name: Keen Smell and Touch
entries: The zombie raccoon has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on smell or touch.

trait.name: Undead Fortitude
entries: If damage reduces the zombie raccoon to 0 hit points, it must make a Constitution saving throw with a DC of 5 + the damage taken, unless the damage is radiant or from a critical hit. On a success, the zombie raccoon drops to 1 hit point instead.

trait.name: Pack Tactics
entries: The zombie raccoon has advantage on an attack roll against a creature if at least one of the raccoon's allies is within 5 feet of the creature and the ally isn't incapacitated.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. {@h}1 ({@damage 1d4}) piercing damage.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. {@h}1 ({@damage 1d4}) slashing damage.

Once ordinary raccoons known for their curiosity and social behavior, these creatures have fallen victim to the scourge of undeath. Most Zombie Raccoons are transformed after scavenging on the remains of other undead creatures, consuming flesh that taints them. This transformation twists their natural instincts and chaotic nature into a more malevolent form.

entries.name: Social Scavengers
entries: Zombie raccoons often roam in packs, which makes them especially dangerous to livestock and humans alike. Their relentless hunger for flesh drives them to work together on ever more clever escapades, coordinating attacks with chilling cunning. Being one of the few animals other than primates to possess opposable thumbs, they have been known to work locks, doors, and set traps that belies their humble origins.

entries.name: Undead Warning
entries: The presence of Zombie Raccoons is often a herald of greater undead activity in the area. As they scavenge what is available, they unwittingly become spreaders of the corruption and quickly throw natural ecosystems out of balance.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about the {@link Zombie Raccoon in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/zombie-raccoon-kRMzfO1jg9}.

item.name: Abi-Tseos's Machete
item.reqAttune: by reading the scrawled phrase on the hilt.
entries: You gain a +3 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon. In addition, the weapon ignores resistance to slashing damage and deals an extra {@dice 2d8} slashing damage to plants and Plant creatures.

The 17-inch blade of this tool-weapon appears deceptively dull and chipped, its hilt is carved azabache (a mystical stone believed to ward off malevolent spirits), and its handle is carved with a disturbing depiction of writhing, bloated leeches. The bohika (shaman) after which the weapon is named used it to wantonly cut down selva and conduct excessive ritual sacrifice to their patron. A lock of unmarred blonde hair dangles from the pommel, its significance lost to time. If the blade is held at the right angle in light, a scrawled phrase appears on the hilt: “A mi, volpal” which translates from its indigenous tongue as “A blade for me.”

When you attack a creature that has at least one head with this weapon and roll a 20 on the attack roll, you cut off one of the creatures heads. The creature dies if it can't survive without the lost head. A creature is immune to this effect if it is immune to slashing damage, doesn't have or need a head, has legendary actions, or the DM decides the creature is too big for its head to be cut off with this weapon. Such a creature takes an extra {@dice 6d8} slashing damage from the hit.

entries.name: Cursed
entries: Whenever you deal damage with Abi-Teos's machete, you take {@dice 1d6} necrotic damage as the weapon drains your blood. If you roll a 1 on an attack roll made with the weapon, the leeches carved into the handle animate and crawl down your throat—infesting you with throat leeches (a disease). You must succeed on a DC 12 Constitution saving throw or gain 1 level of exhaustion that can only be removed by succeeding on a DC 12 Constitution saving throw upon completing a long rest. If the saving throw fails, you gain another level of exhaustion. If a successful saving throw reduces your exhaustion level below 1, you recover from the disease.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about the {@link Abi-Tseos's Machete in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/abi-teoss-machete-ZrSq7FcMTj}.

item.name: Amulet of Betrayal
entries: You can use a bonus action to move one of the following conditions from yourself to an ally within 60 feet of you: {@condition blinded}, {@condition deafened}, {@condition frightened}, {@condition poisoned}, {@condition stunned}, {@condition exhaustion}. When transferring {@condition exhaustion}, move all your {@condition exhaustion} levels. If the chosen ally is immune to a transferred condition, the transfer fails.

This item was once owned by the vampire knight {@link Lamont Solmar|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/lamont-solmar-GLrWBoIX5h}, who served the {@link Lady Nightshade|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/lady-nightshade-3kjLNj2Zbs}.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about the {@link Amulet of Betrayal in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/amulet-of-betrayal-vY1rCwAwHh}.

item.name: Avalon Engineer's Signet
entries: This gilded ring bears a beautiful engraving of a gear and is imbued with the elven magic of {@link Avalon|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/avalon-7amKaC2AMg}. While wearing this ring, you can use an action to cast the {@spell Mending} and {@spell Arcane Lock} spells once each using Intelligence as the spellcasting ability. Once you use the ring to cast the spells, the ring can't be used again until the next dawn.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about the {@link Avalon Engineer's Signet in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/avalon-engineers-signet-63RXQwAWMe}.

item.name: Avalonian Lantern
entries: This elven {@item bullseye lantern|phb} contains a shard of magic crystal that sheds light comparable to that produced by a {@spell continual flame} spell. The lantern is activated by pushing a button on it's side that initiates a series of mechanical gears that perform the spell as a ritual. An Avalonian lantern sheds light in a 120-foot cone; the closest 60 feet is bright light, and the farthest 60 feet is dim light.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about the {@link Avalonian Lantern in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/avalonian-lantern-4rhyHvymXn}.

item.name: Bag of Rust
entries: This ordinary leather bag appears empty. Reaching inside the bag, however, reveals a handful of rust powder.

Once a day, you can use an action to pull rust powder from the bag and throw it up to 20 feet. The powder cloud transforms into a creature you determine by rolling a {@dice d8} and consulting the table.

The creature is friendly to you and your companions, and it acts on your turn. You can use a bonus action to command how the creature moves and what action it takes on its next turn, or to give it general orders, such as to attack your enemies. In the absence of such orders, the creature acts in a fashion appropriate to its nature.
Creatures summoned this way are resistant to necrotic damage.
The creature vanishes at the next dawn or when it is reduced to 0 hit points. At that point, the bag can be used again.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about the {@link Bag of Rust in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/bag-of-rust-SfaknUwwtp}.

item.name: Banshee Blight
entries: Illicit street drug made of ground silvery bark from a type of tree only found deep in swamps. Low dosages are generally taken orally. Heavier users often make a paste to apply to their gums. Addicts may smear it into cuts. Potent stimulant that gives users an adrenaline rush and time seems to slow down, but the duration of the high is short.  Can cause psychosis. Death comes from heart failure, wound infection, self-neglect, or wild magic shock in susceptible individuals. Psychologically addictive not physically.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about {@link Banshee Blight in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/banshee-blight-ziIwCBr2jq}.

item.name: Berserker's Draught
entries: A carbonated and heavily hopped brew contained in a bottle crafted from thick, unpolished amber glass. Instead of a brewer’s mark, the glass is crudely etched by hand with the dwarven rune for “berserker”.

When you drink this beer, you feel the heightened awareness and confidence of an experienced brawler flood through you for 5 minutes. When attacking with an unarmed strike or improvised weapon, you have advantage on the attack roll and can use your bonus action to make another attack of the same type. Your heightened battle focus gives you disadvantage on Wisdom and Intelligence checks and saving throws.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about the {@link Berserker's Draught in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/berserkers-draught-sn5rNNx4Lp}.

fluff.name: Berserker's Draught
entries: While not commercially available, the breweries of {@link Durandar|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/durandar-sWDxZHDVIC} are known for producing all types of experimental concoctions off-label. Variations on the “berserker’s draught” recipe are unique to each brewer and a closely held secret.

item.name: Black Diamond
entries: Illicit street drug magically synthesized from volcanic rock, giving it the appearance of a gray or black crystal. Low dosages are generally smoked in a glass pipe. Addicts may crush it and smear it into cuts. The potent opioid gives users a full-bodied sense of euphoria and brings pain levels down to zero. Death comes from respiratory failure, wound infection and necrosis, and self-neglect. Severely physically addictive. Magic users are immune to its effects.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about {@link Black Diamond in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/black-diamond-pTSDpxQOJ4}.

item.name: Brooch of Witchsight
entries: This ornate brooch is crafted from a dark metal clutching its centerpiece gem - a mesmerizing sapphire that pulses with a spectral light. Inside the gem is a crystalized, unblinking human eyeball - about the size of a child’s.

entries.name: Witchsight
entries: While wearing and attuned to the brooch, the wearer gains {@variantrule Witchsight|dungeonchurch} and can see magical ley lines as glowing paths or streams of energy that traverse the land within a range of 100’.

entries.name: Navigate the Arcane
entries: The wearer gains advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) checks made to navigate or understand the properties of magical locations, including detecting the presence of nearby portals, enchantments, or areas of strong magical influence.

entries.name: Attunement
entries: To attune to the brooch, you must spend a Long Rest meditating on the arcane in an area where ley lines are present.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about the {@link Brooch of Witchsight in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/brooch-of-witchsight-Do7tfU7V9e}.

item.name: Cirilla's Gift
entries: Cirilla's gift is a ring that was worn by the elven battle mage {@link Cirilla of Avalon|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/cirrilla-of-house-naberius-Rx97WvltxP} during the Dragon Wars. After facing a series of defeats on the open battle field, a small group of allies brought the war to the dragon's den. Amongst these was the future dragonborn leader {@link Razorback|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/razorback-the-uniter-O3oe7NBQqK}.

In an attempt to ambush the dragon, Cirilla sacrificed her life in order to save the lives of her friends and defeat the dragon. This set off a cascade of magical effects that resulted in an explosion so powerful that a piece of Cirilla's soul became embedded in the ring, thus imbuing it with its potent and volatile properties.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about {@link Cirilla's Gift in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/cirillas-gift-pKEY4nYJDS}.

item.name: Cloak of Rats
entries: This hooded cloak is made from hundreds of rough leather rat skins, stitched together with twine, and fringed with dessicated rat tails. Wearing this rancid smelling cloak gives the wearer +1 to Constitution saves and allows the attuned wearer to {@spell polymorph} into a {@creature rat} once a day.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about the {@link Cloak of Rats in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/cloak-of-rats-iHIvQwaOt1}.

item.name: Collector of Souls
entries: A black obsidian pyramid covered in runes. Said to be activated by the fresh blood of a dragon, by which it gains the power to collect and free the souls of the draconic damned.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about the {@link Collector of Souls in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/collector-of-souls-XA0hpJ7gfE}.

Said to have been created by {@link Proteus|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/proteus-Apiz4CreFn}, the sahuagin used it as a {@link payment for the illicit arms|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/session-12-13-the-forge-of-fury-m1dOelbiNy#h-the-deal} the gnomes manufactured using the {@link abandoned dwarven forge|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/the-old-mine-ndIfgvk1B6} near {@link Saltmarsh|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/saltmarsh-GkGI6ISio5}.

It later reappeared when a {@link gnomish company|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/the-sunless-temple-1-nine-of-cups-cBaQBejsRH} was tasked with clearing a section of the {@link Sunless Temple|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/sunless-temple-yS5i3gqWiO} that was leaking monsters and mayhem into their {@link Underdark|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/underdark-Lu1sEFgEWw} territory.

Adventurers associated with the {@link Gold Scale Co.|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/gold-scale-company-m1WdlmIYwP} received this relic from the gnomes in the Temple and used it to free the dragonborn souls enslaved by the {@link Knight of Night|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/lamont-solmar-GLrWBoIX5h}.

item.name: Dagger of Profuse Bleeding
entries: This obsidian dagger has a wicked, serrated edge to it that rends flesh as it cuts.

entries.name: Wicked Edge
entries: When you hit a creature with this magic weapon, it causes the target to bleed profusely at even the slightest injury. Because of the amount of blood, they are unable to heal themselves by medicine or magic on their next turn.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about the {@link Dagger of Profuse Bleeding in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/dagger-of-profuse-bleeding-uXUIGCXKkL}.

item.name: Dimensional Glasses
entries: A set of glasses that look like a kaleidoscope from the outside. Looking through them shows vignettes of various planes of existence regularly swapping, overlayed onto the environment around you. They can also be held in place by a switch, useful for creatures feeling homesick.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about the {@link Dimensional Glasses in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/dimensional-glasses-953LlRzRKE}.

item.name: Dream Vine
entries: A fragrant herb often smoked in pipes or hand rolled cigarettes, it has a mild stimulant effect said to encourage conversation and the free flow of ideas. It’s use varies widely by cultural norms. Strictly forbidden in {@link Striborg|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/striborg-mZk9jSyJUV} as an illicit narcotic, it is commonly smoked as part of the cafe culture in {@link New Galmaarden|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/new-galmaarden-03tcpxxc2t}.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about {@link Dream Vine in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/dream-vine-viEBw5FxT7}.

item.name: Entrancing Mirror
entries: These small, handheld mirrors project an inviting, soft blue glow from their surface. When a creature gazes into the mirror, they are presented with a convincing, but distorted, view of themselves and their place in the world. Creatures who gaze habitually into the entrancing mirror come to be susceptible to internalizing it’s false reflection.

For this reason, entrancing mirrors are usually created by unscrupulous warlocks or narcissistic artificers who put them out into the world to feed on the life force that the gazers put into the mirrors. With enough entrancing mirrors in circulation, some of these dark practitioners are able to influence entire populations and thus bend reality closer to the false reflections they conjure.

entries.name: Creeping Influence
entries: Each time a creature gazes into the entrancing mirror, they learn something new, interesting, or delightful but must make a DC 10 Intelligence saving throw. After accumulating 3 fails, they start to identify with the desires of the entrancing mirror’s creator and come under the influence of a {@spell Suggestion} spell. This effect lasts 72 hours, and each subsequent use of the mirror extends this period another 72 hours.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about the {@link Entrancing Mirror in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/entrancing-mirror-LEDVsFaum5}.

item.name: Fedora of Disguise
entries: This hat is patched together out of a motley of many colors and types of materials, forming it into a lumpy fedora shape head covering.
While wearing this fedora, you can use an action to cast the {@spell disguise self} spell from it once a day. The spell ends if the hat is removed. The hat's potential renews at dawn.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about the {@link Fedora of Disguise in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/fedora-of-disguise-c7i4G0ePRf}.

item.name: Fist of Durradin
entries: You gain a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon, and it deals double damage to objects and structures.

A mythical flail forged by the dwarves long ago. It is said to be modeled after the hand of {@link King Durradin|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/king-durradin-SGe3lRM9BN}, though there is no record of the king himself wielding the weapon in battle. Still, the weight of the flail feels light and easy to wield for how heavy it weighs on the scale compared to stone or iron of equal portion.

entries.name: POW!
entries: When you hit a creature for the first time with this weapon, you can force the creature to make a DC 15 Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, the creature is stunned for one round. Deafened creatures are immune. All other creatures who can hear this noise cannot be surprised by it.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about the {@link Fist of Durradin in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/fist-of-durradin-GrRsr84scL}.

item.name: Fiz's Flute
entries: A magical flute that legends claim can slow the passage of time. Once wielded by the notorious trash bard {@link Fiz Junkbrand|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/fiz-junkbrand-6fvhYAH5OE}, ruler of the trash gangs in the abandoned city of {@link Galmaarden|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/new-galmaarden-03tcpxxc2t}.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about {@link Fiz's Flute in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/fizs-flute-ANcBt7lLmj}.

item.name: Gloomroot Extract
entries: A clear, purple-tinted liquid kept in a small wooden bottle that feels cool in your hands, almost as if it draws the warmth from your skin.

When consumed, your visions sharpens and the shadows of the world seem to pulse with unseen energies in time with your heartbeat. You can see invisible creaures and objects for 2 hours as if they are glowing with an ethereal light, giving you advantage on attack rolls against them.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about {@link Gloomroot Extract in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/gloomroot-extract-q9dbCwX0TX}.

Gloomroot is a weed found in only the darkest parts of the {@link Dreadwood|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/dreadwood-GcfKdBzGyT}, where sunlight barely penetrates. It thrives in the rocky soil of ancient ruins, leading some to wonder if it feeds on the remnants of old magic or ground soaked in blood. Chewing the leaves gives a mild stimulant affect that enhances creatures natural darkvision, but the roots can be distilled into an extract with an effect many times stronger.

Locals and hunters in the {@link Dreadwood|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/dreadwood-GcfKdBzGyT} sometimes refer to it as “{@deity Ostara|pyora|dungeonchurch}'s Broom” - a gift from the trickster to help navigate the treacherous paths of the dark forest.

item.name: Gnomish Tea Set
entries: The gnomes are masters of the tea ceremony, and it is rare to find even a halfling on the surface who does not travel with their tea set. While most are made of metal because of it’s durability, each tea set is handcrafted and unique to the person. Some are highly polished works of art, others are more functional in nature and so modified over the years by their user they more resemble some type of clockwork.

{@race Gnome (Rock)|dungeonchurch|Gnomes} are known to use their tea sets in communal rituals that allow them to {@spell Stone Shape} en masse. If enough gnomes participate in this ritual, they can effectively tunnel and travel through solid stone. The exact nature of this {@item Stone Tea|dungeonchurch} and it’s ceremony are a tightly guarded gnomish secret.

entries.name: Stone Tea
entries: Gnomes and halflings who come from Underdark society know the secret of this brew, and an individual with a week’s preparation time and the proper ingredients can summon enough magic to imbue a single tea ceremony ritual with {@spell Stone Shape}. However, {@item Stone Tea|dungeonchurch} is known to induce erratic behavior in individuals who are regularly exposed to sunlight.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about the {@link Gnomish Tea Set in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/gnomish-tea-set-HrqDVlit6V}.

item.name: Guildmaster's Hunting Horn
entries: A polished brass horn, beautifully etched with a scene of dogs pursuing a buck through the woods, and dressed with a leather strap for carrying over the shoulder. Carried by the guildmaster of {@link Burle Hunter's Guild|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/burle-hunters-guild-TFqCs3pSJy} and traditionally blown at the start of their organized hunts and to mark holiday celebrations.

This horn has 2 charges and resets at dawn. Daily you may choose the creature type of your quarry. When you use an action to blow the horn, all creatures that can hear it within 600 feet of your chosen type must make a DC 13 Wisdom saving thrown or be {@condition frightened}.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about the {@link Guildmaster's Hunting Horn in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/guildmasters-hunting-horn-PkmJIssiGT}.

item.name: Ley Line Lens
entries: A focusing monolens with a slender, intricately carved silver frame, containing a ground crystal lens that refracts light into dazzling colors. When held up to the eye, the monocle reveals the hidden paths of ley lines.

entries.name: Witchsight
entries: While looking through the lens, the wearer gains {@variantrule Witchsight|dungeonchurch} and can see magical ley lines as glowing paths or streams of energy that traverse the land within a range of 100’.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about the {@link Ley Line Lens in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/ley-line-lens-A8oN3yTn4x}.

item.name: Longsword of the Dragon Empire
entries: A fine blade with a dark steel hilt in the shape of dragon wings. Issued to officers in the {@link Dragon Empire's|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/dragon-empire-odzVqtQPbm} army, it pulses with a small amount of the draconic fire magic that they are forged in.

entries.name: Draconic Energy
entries: While you are attuned to this longsword, you gain the ability to cast {@spell Fire Bolt}.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about the {@link Longsword of the Dragon Empire in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/longsword-of-the-dragon-empire-WNp5oBATI3}.

item.name: Mage Bane
entries: A blasphemous weapon, made in secret by the Dwarf Council of {@link Durandar|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/durandar-sWDxZHDVIC} behind the back of {@link King Wisebeard|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/king-olfgard-wisebeard-S0YDu9xGHy}.
Formed from a magical, ancient crystal to wield against wizards or magicians who would try to use their influence on the Kingdom.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about the {@link Mage Bane in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/mage-bane-vvIjgk9BDu}.

item.name: Mildred's Amulet
entries: A dark gem mounted in an iron brooch, the hag {@creature Mildred Magpie|dungeonchurch} has imbued it with magic that allows the bearer to reach her across the planes to speak or ask her favor. Whenever the amulet is used, its power must be revived by Mildred's coven.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about {@link Mildred's Amulet in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/mildreds-amulet-rEyfbZD2MW}.

item.name: Minor Belt of Dwarvenkind
entries: A fine woven leather belt of the craftsmanship that all dwarven goods are known for. It's thick, durable leather is meant to hold up the stout belly of a dwarf. Only fits Small or Medium creatures.

entries.name: Friend of the Dwarves
entries: You gain advantage on social interactions when interacting with Dwarves.

entries.name: Dwarf's Pride
entries: While attuned to the belt, you have a 50 percent chance ({@coinflip}) each day at dawn of growing a full beard if you're capable of growing one, or a visibly thicker beard if you already have one.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about the {@link Minor Belt of Dwarvenkind in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/minor-belt-of-dwarvenkind-7pgPJfXTwh}.

item.name: Monster Identification Cards
entries: A set of magical cards from the {@link Saltmarsh|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/saltmarsh-GkGI6ISio5} library that helps adventurers rapidly identify monsters that they are likely to happen upon during the course of their work. When using a card to identify a monster, the user reads the words ‘monstrum novi’ on the front of the card and holds the card so that the card has a view of the monster. On the face of the card will appear the name of the monster, it’s disposition, and a fact of the DM’s choosing. The card then dissolves after 30 minutes, hopefully allowing time for the user to share the information with their cohorts for an advantage in battle or for record keeping.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about the {@link Monster Identification Cards in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/monster-identification-cards-gfyYKrdZLJ}.

item.name: Night Messenger's Cloak
entries: This ankle length purple woolen cloak has a high, flared collar and an elbow length capelet. It has wide, open sleeves and a row of large, silver buttons down one side. At the front corners of the capelet, shadowy horses in rearing stance appear in silver thread.
Worn by members of {@link The Night Messengers|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/the-night-messengers-1lb9etph9O}.

entries.name: Shadow Touched Steed
entries: You can, at will, use the coat cast the spell {@spell Find Steed} to summon a shadow-touched fey mount of your preferred size and type. Summoning the steed takes 1 round. Removing the cloak causes your steed to be dismissed.

entries.name: Witchsight
entries: You can see and sense ley lines and magical trails.

entries.name: Shadow Sense
entries: You have advantage on {@skill Survival} checks made to navigate at night.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about the {@link Night Messenger's Cloak in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/night-messengers-cloak-wPglVS3jpz}.

item.name: Nightshade's Ring
entries: A sapphire encircled in silver by the leaves of a nightshade plant.

{@link Lady Nightshade|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/lady-nightshade-3kjLNj2Zbs} has enchanted this ring so that she knows both the location and the inner emotional state of the person who wears it.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about {@link Nightshade's Ring in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/nightshades-ring-D07HSUmuuy}.

item.name: Nightshade Poison
entries: Made from {@item Sapphire Nightshade|dungeonchurch}. In diluted doses, it acts as other common poisons. In higher concentrations that have been properly distilled it is extremely lethal, and if ingested will kill anyone within minutes. It is the most common tool of the assassin’s trade. It is rumored that when prepared to a high degree of purity, it can cause it’s dead victims to return as undead, monstrously transformed. Many necromancers claim to know the secret of this brew.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about {@link Nightshade Poison in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/nightshade-poison-rGISMbm8AA}.

item.name: Oil of Immolation
entries: This thick, viscous amber liquid is contained with a dark glass and gives off a faint warm heat. It is both a highly unstable compound that ignites at the slightest provocation, and a protection against the effects of fire. Any object or creature that is coated in this oil will burn ferociously for 1 minute, but not suffer any harm or damage.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about the {@link Oil of Immolation in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/oil-of-immolation-nrtJScIEL4}.

entries.name: Provenance
entries: Portrait of {@link Lamont Solmar|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/lamont-solmar-GLrWBoIX5h}, found in the cache of the young black dragon in the {@link Sunless Temple|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/sunless-temple-yS5i3gqWiO}.

Found by {@link Grey Rivermoon|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/grey-rivermoon-p54iB0ukBr}, who recognized it as the man who used to employ him to check in on the {@link Solmar Hunting Lodge|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/solmar-hunting-lodge-TsdtD4GnTp}.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about the {@link Painting of Lamont Solmar in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/painting-of-lamont-solmar-h8zc7ZQfRp}.

item.name: Potion of Incorporeal Passage
entries: A pale, silvery liquid that seems to shimmer and waver like a ghostly apparition contained in a slender, delicate glass bottle. The bottle is sealed with a glass stopper and a metallic pattern is etched into the glass.

For one minute, the drinker is transformed into a ghostly mist and gains the ability to pass through solid objects such as doors or walls no thicker than one foot. Once the passage is made, the effect ends immediately. If passage is attempted through a material too thick, the drinker takes {@dice 3d10} force damage and returns to the spot they started from.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about the {@link Potion of Incorporeal Passage in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/potion-of-incorporeal-passage-izVvGx3r6c}.

item.name: Potion of Midnight Oil
entries: This sludgy, black liquid sloshes with it's own heavy gravity within the bottle. When a humanoid drinks this potion, they gain the benefits of a Long rest. When you complete a long rest after drinking this potion, you gain one level of {@condition exhaustion}.
Drinking more than one Midnight Oil potion at a time has the opposite effect, and puts the drinker to magical sleep for 8 hours and they gain {@dice 1d4} levels of exhaustion upon waking.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about the {@link Potion of Midnight Oil in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/potion-of-midnight-oil-4PiTnJSnnP}.

item.name: Potion of Oblivion
entries: This bottled brew is shaped like an hourglass. When this potion is consumed, it erases the short term memory from the creature's mind. The creature makes a DC 20 Intelligence saving throw. On a success, there is no effect. On a failure, the creature forgets a period of time equal to the number rolled.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about the {@link Potion of Oblivion in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/potion-of-oblivion-DBhlvDmtCl}.

item.name: Potion of Unbridled Potential
entries: This small bottle contains a boiling, iridescent liquid that seems to change colors unpredictably. Captured within this elixir is the raw chaos of magic itself, a boiling miasma of uncontrollable energy. When uncorked, the bottle emits whispers of ancient incantations and forgotten spells, tempting the drinker with the promise of untold power that only they can discover. Giving in to this temptation produces one roll on the {@table Wild Magic Surge|phb} table.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about the {@link Potion of Unbridled Potential in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/potion-of-unbridled-potential-MeZ67CPgHh}.

item.name: Potion of Undeath
entries: When you drink this potion, make a DC 15 Constitution saving throw. On a success, you take {@dice 4d8} necrotic damage and gain one level of exhaustion. If the damage dealt on a success reduces you to zero hit points, you instead suffer the effects of a failure.
On a failure, you fall to zero hit points and cannot receive any magical healing for 8 hours. If you die within 8 hours of drinking this potion, you become a {@creature zombie}.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about the {@link Potion of Undeath in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/potion-of-undeath-RkXumhgmhW}.

item.name: Potion of the Mossy Oak
entries: This deep green potion is thick with suspended bits of bark and leaf. When consumed, it grants the drinker the ability to blend seamlessly with natural surroundings, providing advantage on Stealth checks made in forested areas for 1 hour. Additionally, the potion allows the drinker to communicate with plant life using {@spell Speak with Plants}.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about the {@link Potion of the Mossy Oak in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/potion-of-the-mossy-oak-EUrhe6nCRs}.

item.name: Potion of Vile Strength
entries: This rough stone bottle contains a liquid with the stinging scent of strong alcohol mixed with the metallic iron of fresh blood.

When consumed, a primal force surges through veins of the drinker and their muscles bulge with newfound strength, gaining +2 to Strength checks or saves for 1 hour. Yet this consuming power causes drooling, tics, emotional outbursts, and other anti-social behaviors that cause disadvantage on Charisma checks.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about the {@link Potion of Vile Strength in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/potion-of-vile-strength-v5oDyTkJ2B}.

item.name: Rationing Spice
entries: When applied liberally to food, this reddish powder gives the consumer the feeling that they are eating twice as much and so are satiated on half a normal ration. After three days of eating enchantment spiced food, the consumer must eat a full, hot meal or take one level of exhaustion per day until they do.
Originally developed under the Dragon Empire to stretch their 'labor inputs', it has become a common performance enhancing supplement for soldiers, adventurers, and outdoorsmen of all types.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about {@link Rationing Spice in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/rationing-spice-iguPtdfdS2}.

item.name: Ring of Prestidigitation
entries: While wearing this ring, you can cast the {@spell prestidigitation} spell at will.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about the {@link Ring of Prestidigitation in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/ring-of-prestidigitation-RrfeGNnCzv}.

item.name: Ring of Water Breathing
entries: While wearing this ring, you gain the benefits of a spell of {@spell Water Breathing} on yourself at will without having to cast it. Despite being able to breathe underwater, you cannot speak.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about the {@link Ring of Water Breathing in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/ring-of-water-breathing-hgx2rNwFjj}.

item.name: Sapphire Nightshade
entries: In the depths of the {@link Dreadwood|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/dreadwood-GcfKdBzGyT}, there is rumored to be a rare plant that has thrived in conditions where other flora, fauna and explorers have perished and expired. Adapting to the environment of minimal light and lack of traditional nutrients, this plant has adapted over the centuries by feeding off the insecurities, fears and distress projected by the living beings that pass through this difficult terrain.
Used by some to make a powerful, psychadelic poison.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about {@link Sapphire Nightshade in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/sapphire-nightshade-Qvbjiqksvy}.

item.name: Siduri's Token
entries: A gold coin bearing the emblem of a hop flower one one side and a beer tankard on the other. According to {@race Dwarf (Durandar)|dungeonchurch|Durandian} legends, the rebel god {@deity Siduri|pyora|dungeonchurch} gave their last piece of gold to a blind beggar as they fled prison confinement. That one coin has multiplied across the realm of Pyora, for any who possess one will find two in their pocket when in the company of a true friend. When this token is given or spent in the spirit of friendship, it grants the attuned recipient the ability to {@spell Bless} a single friendly target once per day by using a bonus action to flip the coin.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about {@link Siduri's Token in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/siduris-token-2Bkwhc8XEo}.

item.name: Sphere of Everlasting Ice
entries: A magical sphere of ice that’s cold to the touch but never melts. Just big enough to ice your beverage without it turning to ice itself.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about {@link Sphere of Everlasting Ice in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/sphere-of-everlasting-ice-hjFNSWJiwx}.

item.name: Sporebane
entries: This dagger is covered in a fungal growth that has left a pockmarked patina across it's once lustrous blade. It constantly sheds spores in the air, leaving behind a trail of myconid rot.

A cut from this blade deals an additional {@damage 1d4} necrotic damage if the creature is made of organic matter. On a critical strike, the target must make a {@dc 12} constitution saving throw. On a failed save, the target becomes {@condition paralyzed} until the end of your next turn.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about the {@link Sporebane in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/sporebane-7Fte9HtwL6}.

item.name: Spores of Delirium
entries: This potion is brewed from the rare Violet Frenzy mushrooms that grow only in moonlit clearings of the Dreadwood. The concoction emits a mesmerizing purple haze when opened and exposed to oxygen. Upon consumption, it induces a state of heightened awareness mixed with intense hallucinations. For 30 minutes, the drinker gains the ability to see invisible entities and gains advantage on Perception checks. However, during this period it becomes possible to also have hallucinations. DM will make a private DC 15 Wisdom for the imbiber, and on a failure will introduce hallucinations or false memories at their discretion.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about the {@link Spores of Delirium in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/spores-of-delirium-JpyH7CL4vS}.

item.name: Stone Tea
entries: A ritual tea consumed by gnomes that allows them to travel through stone. Gnomes are known to be fond of tea and carry their complex {@item Gnomish Tea Set|dungeonchurch|tea sets} with them.

The exact ingredients brewed is a closely held secret, but is suspected to contain mushrooms and moonquartz dust. It is known that this tea induces erratic behavior in individuals who are exposed to sunlight on a regular basis.

entries.name: Strange Brew
entries: Gnomes and halflings who come from Underdark society know the secret of this brew, and an individual with a week’s preparation time and the proper ingredients can summon enough magic to imbue a single tea ceremony ritual with {@spell Stone Shape}. However, {@item Stone Tea|dungeonchurch} is known to induce erratic behavior in individuals who are regularly exposed to sunlight.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about the {@link Stone Tea in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/stone-tea-ik79CS5iIM}.

item.name: Shield of Duskmire
entries: A sturdy wooden shield made from mahogany grown in the {@link Dreadwood|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/dreadwood-GcfKdBzGyT}, the front is stained a deep purple and and has a metal inlay of a windmill.
Wearing this shield gives you resistance to poison damage and advantage against being {@condition poisoned}.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about the {@link Shield of Duskmire in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/shield-of-duskmire-8Z1MhlOIXG}.

item.name: Shield of Missile Deflection
entries: While holding this shield, you have resistance to damage from ranged weapon attacks.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about the {@link Shield of Missile Deflection in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/shield-of-missile-deflection-cltEpG9HRg}.

item.name: Skeleton Key
entries: A magical key that can make a perfect copy of any other key. The Key must touch the key it's copying, and it can only change form once every 24 hours.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about the {@link Skeleton Key in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/skeleton-key-aCKEViKMZf}.

item.name: The Red Talon
entries: This preserved dragon claw is dipped in blood and preserved in hardened amber resin. Passed down through the generations by {@link The Red Talon Society|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/the-red-talon-society-tI9out85of}, a group of halfling rangers descended from guerilla fighters in the Dragon Wars, this artifact is a treasured heirloom. It is carefully guarded by the eldest Society halfling, only to be taken out when duty calls on them to strike directly at a dragon or their allies.

entries.name: Enhanced Interrogation
entries: Once per day, the attuned bearer can cast {@spell Detect Thoughts} to sense sympathies toward draconic entities or the use of dragon-related magic.

entries.name: Ancestral Protection
entries: Grants the bearer resistance to fire damage and advantage on saving throws against dragon’s breath weapons.

entries.name: Rally the Resistance
entries: Once per long rest, the bearer can rally allies within 30ft., granting them +1 to attack rolls and saving throws when fighting a dragon or the dragon’s minions for one hour..

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about the {@link The Red Talon in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/the-red-talon-JmZrNqSkRX}.

item.name: Vial of the Last Harvest
entries: This small glass vial contains a single drop of dew from a healthy plant taken at dawn on the first true autumn morning. When ingested by a humanoid, it heals {@dice 2d4+2} hit points.
When used on a plant, it heals any conditions the plant may have and accelerates it’s growth by one good season - including any flowering or fruiting it would naturally do.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about the {@link Vial of the Last Harvest in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/vial-of-the-last-harvest-tsIxDMwTeP}.

item.name: Void Essence
entries: An obsidian bottle, its surface polished to a mirror like sheen that reflects a dark, distorted image. The bubbling liquid inside appears to be boiling, but it is as cold as ice water and smells of carrion and ozone.
Any who manage to quaff it feel a bone-chilling cold, like the touch of death spreading through their veins, gaining resistance to necrotic damage and vulnerability to radiant damage for one hour.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about the {@link Void Essence in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/void-essence-lYJOMctLcD}.

variantrule.name: Long & Short Rests
entries: At the end of both Long & Short rests, a character can spend one or more Hit Dice, up to the character's maximum number of Hit Dice (same as your level). For each Hit Die spent this way, the player rolls the die and adds the CON modifier to it. The player can decide to spend additional die after each roll.
On a long rest, the character also regains spent Hit Dice, up to half the character's level (rounded down).
If sleeping in medium or heavy armor, you regain a quarter of your Hit Dice (minimum one).
Long rests taken in town or otherwise safe place regain all Hit Dice.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about {@link House Rules in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/house-rules-OhKbZs6UV4}.

variantrule.name: Increase HP When Leveling Up
entries: Roll your hit die. You may take either the number you rolled, or the average roll, whichever is higher. The average roll of your hit die is calculated as (rounded down):
( ( Max Die Roll + 1 ) / 2 )

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about {@link House Rules in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/house-rules-OhKbZs6UV4}.

variantrule.name: Witchsight
entries: You can see and sense ley lines and magical trails within a 100' radius as if they were luminous.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about {@link House Rules in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/house-rules-OhKbZs6UV4}.

variantrule.name: Inspiration
entries: When you have Inspiration, you can expend it to give yourself Advantage on a d20 Test. You must decide to do so before rolling.

entries.name: Gaining Inspiration
entries: The DM rewards inspiration for excellent role playing and other whims.

entries.name: One at a Time
entries: You can have one Inspiration at a time. If something gives you Inspiration while you already have it, you can give Inspiration to a player in your group who lacks it.

entries.name: Losing Inspiration
entries: You lose Inspiration at the start of a Long Rest

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about {@link House Rules in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/house-rules-OhKbZs6UV4}.

variantrule.name: Sorcerer: Wild Magic Surge
entries: When the character casts a leveled spell, they roll 1D8. If the roll is equal to or less than the number of spells that have been cast that day, the PC triggers a Wild Magic Surge. When the PC has activated Tides of Chaos, they may surge when casting any subsequent leveled spell of their choosing. All wild magic surges are subject to override at the DM’s discretion.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about {@link House Rules in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/house-rules-OhKbZs6UV4}.

optionalfeature.name: Witchsight
entries: You can see and sense ley lines and magical trails.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about {@link House Rules in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/house-rules-OhKbZs6UV4}.

hazard.name: Sapphire Nightshade Grove
entries: {@item Sapphire Nightshade|dungeonchurch} is a plant that thrives on the darkness and gloom of deep forest, where other things die and rot. It feeds on the insecurities, fears, and distress projected by the living beings that pass through it.
Sapphire Nightshade groves are difficult terrain.

When a player passes through (or very close to) Sapphire Nightshade plants, they must make a DC 15 Constitution check. On a failure, they experience a psychadelic effect that brings them back in their memory to a difficult time, embarassing moment, or other insecurity from their past. On a success or subsequent exposures, they are immune for 24 hours.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about {@link Sapphire Nightshade in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/sapphire-nightshade-Qvbjiqksvy}.

spell.name: Intaglio

components.m: a quill or a vial of ink

entries: You transform a piece of parchment into a duplicate of a text or symbol. While concentrating on this spell, you can use an action to trace your hand over any non-magical text or imagery on a surface within range. You imprint the text or imagery onto parchment you provide, choosing how to resize or crop it. This spell copies a single page with each action, and cannot copy sections larger than 9X12 inches at a time. When copying a spell book, you can do so using the same method as you would replace a spell book, except the time and gp requirements are both halved.
